    <section address="cwnd__oncolorizationcolorchanged">
        <!--60f05072-04e1-454e-8c40-f06ebf835098-->
        <title>CWnd::OnColorizationColorChanged</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member when the rendering policy for the nonclient area has changed.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnColorizationColorChanged(
    DWORD dwColorizationColor, 
    BOOL bOpacity );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Parameter</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Description</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>dwColorizationColor</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Specifies the new colorization color. </para>
                                    <para>The color format is a hexadecimal number of the form 0xAARRGGBB, where each of the four components ranges from 0x00 through 0xFF. The AA component is the alpha value, RR is the color red, GG is green, and BB is blue.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>bOpacity</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para> <codeInline>true</codeInline> if the new color is blended with opacity; <codeInline>false</codeInline> if it is not.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This method receives the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_DWMNCRENDERINGCHANGED</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd388198</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> notification message, which is described in the <token>winSDK</token>. </para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__oncommand">
        <!--478faf4d-728d-4bfb-bca1-76771aeb81ed-->
        <title>CWnd::OnCommand</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the user selects an item from a menu, when a child control sends a notification message, or when an accelerator keystroke is translated.</para>
            <legacySyntax>virtual BOOL OnCommand(
    WPARAM wParam,
    LPARAM lParam );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>wParam</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>The low-order word of <parameterReference>wParam</parameterReference> identifies the command ID of the menu item, control, or accelerator. The high-order word of <parameterReference>wParam</parameterReference> specifies the notification message if the message is from a control. If the message is from an accelerator, the high-order word is 1. If the message is from a menu, the high-order word is 0.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>lParam</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Identifies the control that sends the message if the message is from a control. Otherwise, <parameterReference>lParam</parameterReference> is 0. </para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>An application returns nonzero if it processes this message; otherwise 0.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnCommand</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> processes the message map for control notification and <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>ON_COMMAND</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> entries, and calls the appropriate member function. </para>
                    <para>Override this member function in your derived class to handle the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_COMMAND</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms647591</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> message. An override will not process the message map unless the base class <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnCommand</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> is called.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__oncompacting">
        <!--7d8d7cb3-0a06-448d-8f7c-51ec6d5fbc31-->
        <title>CWnd::OnCompacting</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function for all top-level windows when Windows detects that more than 12.5 percent of system time over a 30- to 60-second interval is being spent compacting memory.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnCompacting( UINT nCpuTime );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm>
                            <legacyItalic>nCpuTime</legacyItalic>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the ratio of CPU time currently spent by Windows compacting memory to CPU time spent performing other operations. For example, 8000h represents 50 percent of CPU time spent compacting memory.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This indicates that system memory is low. </para>
                    <para>When a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object receives this call, it should free as much memory as possible, taking into account the current level of activity of the application and the total number of applications running in Windows. The application can call the Windows function to determine how many applications are running.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__oncompareitem">
        <!--78f49cc9-c119-4cfe-b499-e3421f9b0ea0-->
        <title>CWnd::OnCompareItem</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function to specify the relative position of a new item in a child sorted owner-draw combo or list box.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg int OnCompareItem(
    int nIDCtl,
    LPCOMPAREITEMSTRUCT lpCompareItemStruct );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nIDCtl</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>The identifier of the control that sent the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_COMPAREITEM</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>lpCompareItemStruct</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Contains a long pointer to a <legacyLink xlink:href="4b7131a5-5c7d-4e98-aac7-e85650262b52">COMPAREITEMSTRUCT</legacyLink> data structure that contains the identifiers and application-supplied data for two items in the combo or list box.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Indicates the relative position of the two items. It may be any of the following values:</para>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Value</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Meaning</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>1</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Item 1 sorts before item 2.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>0</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Item 1 and item 2 sort the same.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>1</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Item 1 sorts after item 2.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>If a combo or list box is created with the <legacyLink xlink:href="d21a5023-e6a2-495b-a6bd-010a515cbc63">CBS_SORT</legacyLink> or <legacyLink xlink:href="3f357b8d-9118-4f41-9e28-02ed92d1e88f">LBS_SORT</legacyLink> style, Windows sends the combo-box or list-box owner a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_COMPAREITEM</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message whenever the application adds a new item.</para>
                    <para>Two items in the combo or list box are reformed in a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>COMPAREITEMSTRUCT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> structure pointed to by <parameterReference>lpCompareItemStruct</parameterReference>. <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnCompareItem</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> should return a value that indicates which of the items should appear before the other. Typically, Windows makes this call several times until it determines the exact position for the new item.</para>
                    <para>If the <legacyBold>hwndItem</legacyBold> member of the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>COMPAREITEMSTRUCT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> structure belongs to a <legacyLink xlink:href="7ba3c699-c286-4cd9-9066-532c41ec05d1">CListBox</legacyLink> or <legacyLink xlink:href="4e73b5df-0d2e-4658-9706-38133fb10513">CComboBox</legacyLink> object, then the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CompareItem</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> virtual function of the appropriate class is called. Override <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CComboBox::CompareItem</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> or <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CListBox::CompareItem</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> in your derived <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CListBox</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> or <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CComboBox</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> class to do the item comparison.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__oncompositionchanged">
        <!--9464ac27-3380-4cd0-af3f-93e71ea5a288-->
        <title>CWnd::OnCompositionChanged</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function for all top-level windows when the Desktop Window Manager (DWM) composition is enabled or disabled.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnCompositionChanged();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This method receives the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_DWMCOMPOSITIONCHANGED</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd388199</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> notification, which is described in the <token>winSDK</token>. </para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__oncontextmenu">
        <!--0fa9df29-0c6f-411b-af7f-fac7a1af337e-->
        <title>CWnd::OnContextMenu</title>
        <content>
            <para>Called by the framework when the user has clicked the right mouse button (right clicked) in the window.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnContextMenu(
    CWnd* pWnd,
    CPoint pos );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pWnd</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Handle to the window in which the user right clicked the mouse. This can be a child window of the window receiving the message. For more information about processing this message, see the Remarks section.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pos</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para> Position of the cursor, in screen coordinates, at the time of the mouse click.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>You can process this message by displaying a context menu using the <legacyLink xlink:href="40cacfdc-d45c-4ec7-bf28-991c72812499#cmenu__trackpopupmenu">TrackPopupMenu</legacyLink>.</para>
                    <para>If you do not display a context menu you should pass this message onto the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__defwindowproc">DefWindowProc</legacyLink> function. If your window is a child window, <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>DefWindowProc</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> sends the message to the parent. Otherwise, <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>DefWindowProc</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> displays a default context menu if the specified position is in the window's caption.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__oncopydata">
        <!--0dbf3e98-92ef-4a4d-95fa-14a78bbcc593-->
        <title>CWnd::OnCopyData</title>
        <content>
            <para>This member function is called by the framework to copy data from one application to another.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg BOOL OnCopyData(
    CWnd* pWnd,
    COPYDATASTRUCT* pCopyDataStruct );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pWnd</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>A pointer to a <legacyLink xlink:href="49a832ee-bc34-4126-88b3-bc1d9974f6c4">CWnd</legacyLink> object that is sending the data.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pCopyDataStruct</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>A pointer to a                                 <externalLink> <linkText>COPYDATASTRUCT</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms649010</linkUri>
                                </externalLink> structure that contains the data being sent.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Returns <legacyBold>TRUE</legacyBold> if the receiving application successfully accepts the data. Otherwise, returns <legacyBold>FALSE</legacyBold>.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The data being passed must not contain pointers or other references to objects not accessible to the application receiving the data.</para>
                    <para>While the data is being copied, it must not be changed by another thread of the sending process.</para>
                    <para>The receiving application should consider the data read-only. The structure pointed to by the parameter <parameterReference>pCopyDataStruct</parameterReference> is valid only during the transfer of data; however, the receiving application should not free the memory associated with the structure. </para>
                    <para>If the receiving application needs access to the data after this function returns, it must copy the data received to a local buffer.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__oncreate">
        <!--f18422cb-350e-4a0f-a234-2575a3b1980a-->
        <title>CWnd::OnCreate</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when an application requests that the Windows window be created by calling the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__create">Create</legacyLink> or <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__createex">CreateEx</legacyLink> member function.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg int OnCreate( LPCREATESTRUCT lpCreateStruct );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>lpCreateStruct</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Points to a <legacyLink xlink:href="028c7b5e-4fdc-48da-a550-d3e4f9e6cc85">CREATESTRUCT</legacyLink> structure that contains information about the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object being created.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnCreate</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> must return 0 to continue the creation of the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object. If the application returns 1, the window will be destroyed.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object receives this call after the window is created but before it becomes visible. <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnCreate</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> is called before the <legacyBold>Create</legacyBold> or <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CreateEx</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function returns. </para>
                    <para>Override this member function to perform any needed initialization of a derived class. </para>
                    <para>The <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CREATESTRUCT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> structure contains copies of the parameters used to create the window.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onctlcolor">
        <!--e97957d7-7c6c-4ff6-b8f5-bc9fe2cd05b1-->
        <title>CWnd::OnCtlColor</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when a child control is about to be drawn.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg HBRUSH OnCtlColor(
    CDC* pDC,
    CWnd* pWnd,
    UINT nCtlColor );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pDC</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Contains a pointer to the display context for the child window. May be temporary.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pWnd</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Contains a pointer to the control asking for the color. May be temporary.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nCtlColor</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Contains one of the following values, specifying the type of control:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>CTLCOLOR_BTN</legacyBold>Button control</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>CTLCOLOR_DLG</legacyBold>Dialog box</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>CTLCOLOR_EDIT</legacyBold>Edit control</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>CTLCOLOR_LISTBOX</legacyBold>List-box control</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>CTLCOLOR_MSGBOX</legacyBold>Message box</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>CTLCOLOR_SCROLLBAR</legacyBold>Scroll-bar control</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>CTLCOLOR_STATIC</legacyBold>Static control</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnCtlColor</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> must return a handle to the brush that is to be used for painting the control background.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Most controls send this message to their parent (usually a dialog box) to prepare the <parameterReference>pDC</parameterReference> for drawing the control using the correct colors.</para>
                    <para>To change the text color, call the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>SetTextColor</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function with the desired red, green, and blue (RGB) values. </para>
                    <para>To change the background color of a single-line edit control, set the brush handle in both the <legacyBold>CTLCOLOR_EDIT</legacyBold> and <legacyBold>CTLCOLOR_MSGBOX</legacyBold> message codes, and call the <legacyLink xlink:href="715b3334-cb2b-4c9c-8067-02eb7c66c8b2#cdc__setbkcolor">CDC::SetBkColor</legacyLink> function in response to the <legacyBold>CTLCOLOR_EDIT</legacyBold> code.</para>
                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnCtlColor</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> will not be called for the list box of a drop-down combo box because the drop-down list box is actually a child of the combo box and not a child of the window. To change the color of the drop-down list box, create a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CComboBox</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> with an override of <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnCtlColor</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> that checks for <legacyBold>CTLCOLOR_LISTBOX</legacyBold> in the <parameterReference>nCtlColor</parameterReference> parameter. In this handler, the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>SetBkColor</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function must be used to set the background color for the text.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function. To add the following method to your dialog class, use the Visual Studio properties pane to add a message handler for WM_CTLCOLOR. Alternatively, you can manually add an ON_WM_CTLCOLOR() entry to the message map.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Example</title>
                <content>
                    <codeReference>NVC_MFCWindowing#107</codeReference>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ondeadchar">
        <!--6d0e3d09-ab72-4715-aae8-fe825eb02f66-->
        <title>CWnd::OnDeadChar</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onkeyup">OnKeyUp</legacyLink> member function and the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onkeydown">OnKeyDown</legacyLink> member functions are called.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnDeadChar(
    UINT nChar,
    UINT nRepCnt,
    UINT nFlags );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nChar</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the dead-key character value.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nRepCnt</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the repeat count.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the scan code, key-transition code, previous key state, and context code, as shown in the following list:</para>
                            <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                                <thead>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Value</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Description</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                </thead>
                                <tbody>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>07</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Scan code (OEM-dependent value). Low byte of high-order word.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>8</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Extended key, such as a function key or a key on the numeric keypad (1 if it is an extended key; otherwise 0).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>910</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Not used.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>1112</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Used internally by Windows.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>13</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Context code (1 if the ALT key is held down while the key is pressed; otherwise 0).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>14</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Previous key state (1 if the key is down before the call, 0 if the key is up).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>15</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Transition state (1 if the key is being released, 0 if the key is being pressed).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                </tbody>
                            </table>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This member function can be used to specify the character value of a dead key. A dead key is a key, such as the umlaut (double-dot) character, that is combined with other characters to form a composite character. For example, the umlaut-O character consists of the dead key, umlaut, and the O key.</para>
                    <para>An application typically uses <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnDeadChar</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> to give the user feedback about each key pressed. For example, an application can display the accent in the current character position without moving the caret. </para>
                    <para>Since there is not necessarily a one-to-one correspondence between keys pressed and <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnDeadChar</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> calls, the information in <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference> is generally not useful to applications. The information in <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference> applies only to the most recent call to the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onkeyup">OnKeyUp</legacyLink> member function or the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onkeydown">OnKeyDown</legacyLink> member function that precedes the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnDeadChar</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> call.</para>
                    <para>For IBM Enhanced 101- and 102-key keyboards, enhanced keys are the right ALT and the right CTRL keys on the main section of the keyboard; the INS, DEL, HOME, END, PAGE UP, PAGE DOWN, and arrow keys in the clusters to the left of the numeric keypad; and the slash (/) and ENTER keys in the numeric keypad. Some other keyboards may support the extended-key bit in <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ondeleteitem">
        <!--8d3ca9c7-7496-4520-a35d-0cbcb736251d-->
        <title>CWnd::OnDeleteItem</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function to inform the owner of an owner-draw list box or combo box that the list box or combo box is destroyed or that items have been removed by <legacyLink xlink:href="4e73b5df-0d2e-4658-9706-38133fb10513#ccombobox__deletestring">CComboBox::DeleteString</legacyLink>, <legacyLink xlink:href="7ba3c699-c286-4cd9-9066-532c41ec05d1#clistbox__deletestring">CListBox::DeleteString</legacyLink>, <legacyLink xlink:href="4e73b5df-0d2e-4658-9706-38133fb10513#ccombobox__resetcontent">CComboBox::ResetContent</legacyLink>, or <legacyLink xlink:href="7ba3c699-c286-4cd9-9066-532c41ec05d1#clistbox__resetcontent">CListBox::ResetContent</legacyLink>.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnDeleteItem(
    int nIDCtl,
    LPDELETEITEMSTRUCT lpDeleteItemStruct );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nIDCtl</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>The identifier of the control that sent the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_DELETEITEM</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>lpDeleteItemStruct</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies a long pointer to a <legacyLink xlink:href="48d3998c-f4a8-402a-bf90-df3770a78685">DELETEITEMSTRUCT</legacyLink> data structure that contains information about the deleted list box item.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>If the <legacyBold>hwndItem</legacyBold> member of the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>DELETEITEMSTRUCT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> structure belongs to a combo box or list box, then the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>DeleteItem</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> virtual function of the appropriate class is called. Override the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>DeleteItem</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function of the appropriate control's class to delete item-specific data.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ondestroy">
        <!--1cfc8ce5-1aba-4da6-bb5b-fe81d52dcda4-->
        <title>CWnd::OnDestroy</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function to inform the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object that it is being destroyed.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnDestroy();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnDestroy</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> is called after the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object is removed from the screen. </para>
                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnDestroy</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> is called first for the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> being destroyed, then for the child windows of <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> as they are destroyed. It can be assumed that all child windows still exist while <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnDestroy</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> runs. </para>
                    <para>If the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object being destroyed is part of the Clipboard-viewer chain (set by calling the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__setclipboardviewer">SetClipboardViewer</legacyLink> member function), the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> must remove itself from the Clipboard-viewer chain by calling the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__changeclipboardchain">ChangeClipboardChain</legacyLink> member function before returning from the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnDestroy</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> function.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ondestroyclipboard">
        <!--dc94e325-2859-4870-b232-0640e7b49a57-->
        <title>CWnd::OnDestroyClipboard</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function for the Clipboard owner when the Clipboard is emptied through a call to the                 <externalLink> <linkText>EmptyClipboard</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms649037</linkUri>
                </externalLink> Windows function.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnDestroyClipboard();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections/>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ondevicechange">
        <!--78ef17c3-51e9-4673-8717-25c3599b5523-->
        <title>CWnd::OnDeviceChange</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function to notify an application or device driver of a change to the hardware configuration of a device or the computer.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg BOOL OnDeviceChange(
    UINT nEventType,
    DWORD_PTR dwData );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm>
                            <legacyItalic>nEventType</legacyItalic>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>An event type. See the Remarks section for a description of the available values</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>dwData</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>The address of a structure that contains event-specific data. Its meaning depends on the given event.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>For devices that offer software-controllable features, such as ejection and locking, the operating system typically sends a <legacyBold>DBT_DEVICEREMOVEPENDING </legacyBold>message to let applications and device drivers end their use of the device gracefully. </para>
                    <para>If the operating system forcefully removes of a device, it may not send a <legacyBold>DBT_DEVICEQUERYREMOVE</legacyBold> message before doing so.</para>
                    <para>The                         <legacyItalic>nEvent</legacyItalic> parameter can be one of these values:  </para>
                    <list class="bullet">
                        <listItem>
                            <para>
                                <externalLink> <linkText>DBT_DEVICEARRIVAL</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa363205</linkUri>
                                </externalLink>A device has been inserted and is now available. </para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para>
                                <externalLink> <linkText>DBT_DEVICEQUERYREMOVE</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa363206</linkUri>
                                </externalLink>Permission to remove a device is requested. Any application can deny this request and cancel the removal.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para>
                                <externalLink> <linkText>DBT_DEVICEQUERYREMOVEFAILED</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa363207</linkUri>
                                </externalLink>Request to remove a device has been canceled.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para>
                                <externalLink> <linkText>DBT_DEVICEREMOVEPENDING</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa363209</linkUri>
                                </externalLink>Device is about to be removed. Cannot be denied.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para>
                                <externalLink> <linkText>DBT_DEVICEREMOVECOMPLETE</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa363208</linkUri>
                                </externalLink>Device has been removed.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para>
                                <externalLink> <linkText>DBT_DEVICETYPESPECIFIC</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa363210</linkUri>
                                </externalLink>Device-specific event.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para>
                                <externalLink> <linkText>DBT_CONFIGCHANGED</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa363203</linkUri>
                                </externalLink>Current configuration has changed.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>DBT_DEVNODES_CHANGED</legacyBold>Device node has changed.</para>
                        </listItem>
                    </list>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ondevmodechange">
        <!--532766ad-0e2f-4b76-9a79-e1cdcb7a580d-->
        <title>CWnd::OnDevModeChange</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function for all top-level <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> objects when the user changes device-mode settings.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnDevModeChange( LPTSTR lpDeviceName );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm>
                            <legacyItalic>lpDeviceName</legacyItalic>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Points to the device name specified in the Windows initialization file, WIN.INI.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Applications that handle the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_DEVMODECHANGE</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message may reinitialize their device-mode settings. Applications that use the Windows <legacyBold>ExtDeviceMode</legacyBold> function to save and restore device settings typically do not process this function. </para>
                    <para>This function is not called when the user changes the default printer from Control Panel. In this case, the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnWinIniChange</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> function is called.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ondrawclipboard">
        <!--37c84660-2d52-4f73-808b-df34642ee820-->
        <title>CWnd::OnDrawClipboard</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function for each window in the Clipboard-viewer chain when the contents of the Clipboard change.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnDrawClipboard();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Only applications that have joined the Clipboard-viewer chain by calling the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__setclipboardviewer">SetClipboardViewer</legacyLink> member function need to respond to this call. </para>
                    <para>Each window that receives an <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnDrawClipboard</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> call should call the                         <externalLink> <linkText>SendMessage</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms644950</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function to pass a                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_DRAWCLIPBOARD</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms649025</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> message on to the next window in the Clipboard-viewer chain. The handle of the next window is returned by the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__setclipboardviewer">SetClipboardViewer</legacyLink> member function; it may be modified in response to an <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onchangecbchain">OnChangeCbChain</legacyLink> member function call.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ondrawiconicthumbnailorlivepreview">
        <!--88781cfd-be52-41af-b48f-587befce7307-->
        <title>CWnd::OnDrawIconicThumbnailOrLivePreview</title>
        <content>
            <para>Called by the framework when it needs to obtain a bitmap to be displayed on Windows 7 tab thumbnail, or on the client for application peek.</para>
            <legacySyntax>virtual void OnDrawIconicThumbnailOrLivePreview(
    CDC&amp; dc,
    CRect rect,
    CSize szRequiredThumbnailSize,
    BOOL bIsThumbnail,
    BOOL&amp; bAlphaChannelSet );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>dc</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the device context.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>rect</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the bounding rectangle of the area to render.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>szRequiredThumbnailSize</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the size of the target thumbnail. Should be ignored if <parameterReference>bIsThumbnail</parameterReference> is <languageKeyword>FALSE</languageKeyword>.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>bIsThumbnail</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies whether this method is called for iconic thumbnail or live preview (peek).</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>bAlphaChannelSet</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>[out] Set it to <languageKeyword>TRUE</languageKeyword> if your implementation initializes the alpha channel of a bitmap selected in <parameterReference>dc</parameterReference>.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Override this method in a derived class and draw on the specified device context in order to customize thumbnail and peek. If <parameterReference>bThumbnail</parameterReference> is <languageKeyword>TRUE</languageKeyword>, <parameterReference>szRequiredThumbnailSize</parameterReference> can be ignored. In this case you should be aware that you draw full sized bitmap (that is, a bitmap that covers the whole client area). The device context ( <parameterReference>dc</parameterReference>) comes with selected 32 bits bitmap. The default implementation sends WM_PRINT to this window with PRF_CLIENT, PRF_CHILDREN, and PRF_NONCLIENT flags.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ondrawitem">
        <!--1dc50277-7b58-41bb-891d-8c592483b5c6-->
        <title>CWnd::OnDrawItem</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function for the owner of an owner-draw button control, combo-box control, list-box control, or menu when a visual aspect of the control or menu has changed.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnDrawItem(
    int nIDCtl,
    LPDRAWITEMSTRUCT lpDrawItemStruct );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nIDCtl</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Contains the identifier of the control that sent the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_DRAWITEM</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message. If a menu sent the message, <parameterReference>nIDCtl</parameterReference> contains 0.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>lpDrawItemStruct</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies a long pointer to a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>DRAWITEMSTRUCT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> data structure that contains information about the item to be drawn and the type of drawing required.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The <legacyBold>itemAction</legacyBold> member of the <legacyLink xlink:href="ba9ef1d4-aebb-45e9-b956-4b81a02e50f7">DRAWITEMSTRUCT</legacyLink> structure defines the drawing operation that is to be performed. The data in this member allows the owner of the control to determine what drawing action is required. </para>
                    <para>Before returning from processing this message, an application should ensure that the device context identified by the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>hDC</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member of the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>DRAWITEMSTRUCT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> structure is restored to the default state.</para>
                    <para>If the <legacyBold>hwndItem</legacyBold> member belongs to a <legacyLink xlink:href="cdc76d5b-31da-43c5-bc43-fde4cb39de5b">CButton</legacyLink>, <legacyLink xlink:href="40cacfdc-d45c-4ec7-bf28-991c72812499">CMenu</legacyLink>, <legacyLink xlink:href="7ba3c699-c286-4cd9-9066-532c41ec05d1">CListBox</legacyLink>, or <legacyLink xlink:href="4e73b5df-0d2e-4658-9706-38133fb10513">CComboBox</legacyLink> object, then the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>DrawItem</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> virtual function of the appropriate class is called. Override the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>DrawItem</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function of the appropriate control's class to draw the item.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ondropfiles">
        <!--e85baebb-c8fa-4020-bc8b-aca481ceb58d-->
        <title>CWnd::OnDropFiles</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the user releases the left mouse button over a window that has registered itself as the recipient of dropped files.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnDropFiles( HDROP hDropInfo );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm>
                            <legacyItalic>hDropInfo</legacyItalic>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>A pointer to an internal data structure that describes the dropped files. This handle is used by the <legacyBold>DragFinish</legacyBold>, <legacyBold>DragQueryFile</legacyBold>, and <legacyBold>DragQueryPoint</legacyBold> Windows functions to retrieve information about the dropped files.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Typically, a derived class will be designed to support dropped files and it will register itself during window construction.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onenable">
        <!--a5a63397-c8d8-485f-b287-d185a9316886-->
        <title>CWnd::OnEnable</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when an application changes the enabled state of the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnEnable( BOOL bEnable );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>bEnable</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies whether the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object has been enabled or disabled. This parameter is <legacyBold>TRUE</legacyBold> if the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> has been enabled; it is <legacyBold>FALSE</legacyBold> if the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> has been disabled.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnEnable</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> is called before the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__enablewindow">EnableWindow</legacyLink> member function returns, but after the window enabled state ( <legacyLink xlink:href="c85ffbe4-f4ff-4227-917a-48ec4a411842">WS_DISABLED</legacyLink> style bit) has changed.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onendsession">
        <!--e90c94a3-5589-41c7-8f13-464a1351075d-->
        <title>CWnd::OnEndSession</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function after the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object has returned a nonzero value from a <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onqueryendsession">OnQueryEndSession</legacyLink> member function call.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnEndSession( BOOL bEnding );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>bEnding</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies whether or not the session is being ended. It is <legacyBold>TRUE</legacyBold> if the session is being ended; otherwise <legacyBold>FALSE</legacyBold>.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnEndSession</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> call informs the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object whether the session is actually ending. </para>
                    <para>If <parameterReference>bEnding</parameterReference> is <legacyBold>TRUE</legacyBold>, Windows can terminate any time after all applications have returned from processing this call. Consequently, have an application perform all tasks required for termination within <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnEndSession</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>. </para>
                    <para>You do not need to call the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__destroywindow">DestroyWindow</legacyLink> member function or                         <externalLink> <linkText>PostQuitMessage</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms644945</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function when the session is ending.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onenteridle">
        <!--15e3a108-7e69-4be2-a1b0-b93a62e05fed-->
        <title>CWnd::OnEnterIdle</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function to inform an application's main window procedure that a modal dialog box or a menu is entering an idle state.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnEnterIdle(
    UINT nWhy,
    CWnd* pWho );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nWhy</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies whether the message is the result of a dialog box or a menu being displayed. This parameter can be one of the following values:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MSGF_DIALOGBOX</legacyBold>The system is idle because a dialog box is being displayed.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MSGF_MENU</legacyBold>The system is idle because a menu is being displayed.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm>
                            <legacyItalic>pWho</legacyItalic>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies a pointer to the dialog box (if <parameterReference>nWhy</parameterReference> is <legacyBold>MSGF_DIALOGBOX</legacyBold>), or the window that contains the displayed menu (if <parameterReference>nWhy</parameterReference> is <legacyBold>MSGF_MENU</legacyBold>). This pointer may be temporary and should not be stored for later use.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>A modal dialog box or menu enters an idle state when no messages are waiting in its queue after it has processed one or more previous messages.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onentermenuloop">
        <!--35220fc1-6384-41ad-9663-3546266cac10-->
        <title>CWnd::OnEnterMenuLoop</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when a menu modal loop has been entered.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnEnterMenuLoop( BOOL bIsTrackPopupMenu );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
