                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies whether the menu involved is a popup menu. Has a nonzero value if the function is successful; otherwise 0.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onentersizemove">
        <!--5ae74c25-160a-4b9b-b9ad-a4599cd8986d-->
        <title>CWnd::OnEnterSizeMove</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function one time after the affected window enters a moving or sizing modal loop.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnEnterSizeMove();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This method receives the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_ENTERSIZEMOVE</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms632622</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> notification, which is described in the <token>winSDK</token>. </para>
                    <para>A window enters a moving or sizing modal loop when the user clicks the window's title bar or sizing border, or when the window passes the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_SYSCOMMAND</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms646360</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> message to the <link xlink:href="#cwnd__defwindowproc">CWnd::DefWindowProc</link> function and the <codeInline> wParam </codeInline>parameter of that message specifies <codeInline>SC_MOVE</codeInline> or <codeInline>SC_SIZE</codeInline>.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onerasebkgnd">
        <!--8ec6806f-fd8b-4190-b469-0367d2b29dad-->
        <title>CWnd::OnEraseBkgnd</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object background needs erasing (for example, when resized).</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg BOOL OnEraseBkgnd( CDC* pDC );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pDC</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the device-context object.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Nonzero if it erases the background; otherwise 0.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>It is called to prepare an invalidated region for painting.</para>
                    <para>The default implementation erases the background using the window class background brush specified by the <legacyBold>hbrBackground</legacyBold> member of the window class structure. </para>
                    <para>If the <legacyBold>hbrBackground</legacyBold> member is <legacyBold>NULL</legacyBold>, your overridden version of <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnEraseBkgnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> should erase the background color. Your version should also align the origin of the intended brush with the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> coordinates by first calling                         <externalLink> <linkText>UnrealizeObject</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd145164</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> for the brush, and then selecting the brush.</para>
                    <para>An overridden <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnEraseBkgnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> should return nonzero in response to <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_ERASEBKGND</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> if it processes the message and erases the background; this indicates that no further erasing is required. If it returns 0, the window will remain marked as needing to be erased. (Typically, this means that the <legacyBold>fErase</legacyBold> member of the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PAINTSTRUCT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> structure will be <legacyBold>TRUE</legacyBold>.) </para>
                    <para>Windows assumes the background is computed with the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>MM_TEXT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> mapping mode. If the device context is using any other mapping mode, the area erased may not be within the visible part of the client area.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>

    <section address="cwnd__onfontchange">
        <!--bb012d2e-5bcc-49ce-a1bf-c5c2ee1f1e7d-->
        <title>CWnd::OnFontChange</title>
        <content>
            <para>All top-level windows in the system receive an <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnFontChange</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> call from the framework after the application changes the pool of font resources.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnFontChange();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>An application that adds or removes fonts from the system (for example, through the                         <externalLink> <linkText>AddFontResource</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd183326</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> or                         <externalLink> <linkText>RemoveFontResource</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd162922</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function) should send the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_FONTCHANGE</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd145211</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> message to all top-level windows. </para>
                    <para>To send this message, use the                         <externalLink> <linkText>SendMessage</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms644950</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function with the <parameterReference>hWnd</parameterReference> parameter set to <legacyBold>HWND_BROADCAST</legacyBold>.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ongetdlgcode">
        <!--614afa07-f1a6-475a-b600-0883529c7c54-->
        <title>CWnd::OnGetDlgCode</title>
        <content>
            <para>Called for a control so the control can process arrow-key and TAB-key input itself.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg UINT OnGetDlgCode();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>One or more of the following values, indicating which type of input the application processes:  </para>
                    <list class="bullet">
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>DLGC_BUTTON</legacyBold>Button (generic).</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>DLGC_DEFPUSHBUTTON</legacyBold>Default pushbutton.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>DLGC_HASSETSEL</legacyBold> <legacyBold>EM_SETSEL</legacyBold> messages.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>DLGC_UNDEFPUSHBUTTON</legacyBold>No default pushbutton processing. (An application can use this flag with <legacyBold>DLGC_BUTTON</legacyBold> to indicate that it processes button input but relies on the system for default pushbutton processing.)</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>DLGC_RADIOBUTTON</legacyBold>Radio button.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>DLGC_STATIC</legacyBold>Static control.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>DLGC_WANTALLKEYS</legacyBold>All keyboard input.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>DLGC_WANTARROWS</legacyBold>Arrow keys.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>DLGC_WANTCHARS</legacyBold> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_CHAR</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> messages.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>DLGC_WANTMESSAGE</legacyBold>All keyboard input. The application passes this message on to the control.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>DLGC_WANTTAB</legacyBold>TAB key.</para>
                        </listItem>
                    </list>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Normally, Windows handles all arrow-key and TAB-key input to a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> control. By overriding <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnGetDlgCode</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> control can choose a particular type of input to process itself. </para>
                    <para>The default <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnGetDlgCode</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> functions for the predefined control classes return a code appropriate for each class.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ongetminmaxinfo">
        <!--2a89d834-3f43-456a-a000-34a011febe68-->
        <title>CWnd::OnGetMinMaxInfo</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function whenever Windows needs to know the maximized position or dimensions, or the minimum or maximum tracking size.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnGetMinMaxInfo( MINMAXINFO* lpMMI );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm>
                            <legacyItalic>lpMMI</legacyItalic>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Points to a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>MINMAXINFO</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> structure that contains information about a window's maximized size and position and its minimum and maximum tracking size. For more about this structure, see the <legacyLink xlink:href="be6fb578-f98a-4581-9ada-be9df308ed2f">MINMAXINFO</legacyLink> structure.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The maximized size is the size of the window when its borders are fully extended. The maximum tracking size of the window is the largest window size that can be achieved by using the borders to size the window. The minimum tracking size of the window is the smallest window size that can be achieved by using the borders to size the window. </para>
                    <para>Windows fills in an array of points specifying default values for the various positions and dimensions. The application may change these values in <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnGetMinMaxInfo</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>

    <section address="cwnd__onhelpinfo">
        <!--bf884ab0-0f48-4e31-a82c-8f52ea9619e0-->
        <title>CWnd::OnHelpInfo</title>
        <content>
            <para>Called by the framework when the user presses the F1 key.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg BOOL OnHelpInfo( HELPINFO* lpHelpInfo );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm>
                            <legacyItalic>lpHelpInfo</legacyItalic>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Pointer to a                                 <externalLink> <linkText>HELPINFO</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/bb773313</linkUri>
                                </externalLink> structure that contains information about the menu item, control, dialog box, or window for which help is requested.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Returns TRUE if a window has the keyboard focus or if a menu is active within a window. If no window has the keyboard focus, returns FALSE.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>If a menu is active when F1 is pressed, <legacyBold>WM_HELP</legacyBold> is sent to the window associated with the menu; otherwise, <legacyBold>WM_HELP</legacyBold> is sent to the window that has the keyboard focus. If no window has the keyboard focus, <legacyBold>WM_HELP</legacyBold> is sent to the currently active window.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>

    <section address="cwnd__onhotkey">
        <!--e3032776-4bc4-46f5-bddc-700a246ca359-->
        <title>CWnd::OnHotKey</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the user presses a system-wide hot key.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnHotKey(
    UINT nHotKeyId, 
    UINT nKey1, 
    UINT nKey2 );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Parameter</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Description</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>nHotKeyId</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Identifier for the hot key that generated the message. If the message was generated by a system-defined hot key, this parameter will be one of the following values:</para>
                                    <list class="bullet">
                                        <listItem>
                                            <para> <codeInline>IDHOT_SNAPDESKTOP</codeInline> - The snap desktop hot key was pressed.</para>
                                        </listItem>
                                        <listItem>
                                            <para> <codeInline>IDHOT_SNAPWINDOW</codeInline> - The snap window hot key was pressed.</para>
                                        </listItem>
                                    </list>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>nKey1</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>A bitwise combination (OR) of flags that indicate the keys that were pressed in combination with the key specified by the <parameterReference>nKey2</parameterReference> parameter. The possible values are:</para>
                                    <list class="bullet">
                                        <listItem>
                                            <para> <codeInline>MOD_ALT</codeInline> - Either ALT key was held down.</para>
                                        </listItem>
                                        <listItem>
                                            <para> <codeInline>MOD_CONTROL</codeInline> - Either CTRL key was held down.</para>
                                        </listItem>
                                        <listItem>
                                            <para> <codeInline>MOD_SHIFT</codeInline> - Either SHIFT key was held down.</para>
                                        </listItem>
                                        <listItem>
                                            <para> <codeInline>MOD_WIN</codeInline> - Either WINDOWS key was held down. These keys are labeled with the Microsoft Windows logo.</para>
                                        </listItem>
                                    </list>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>nKey2</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>The virtual key code of the hot key. </para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This method receives the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_HOTKEY</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms646279</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> notification, which is described in the <token>winSDK</token>. This message is placed at the top of the message queue associated with the thread that registered the hot key. Use the                         <externalLink> <linkText>RegisterHotKey</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms646309</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> function to register a system-wide hot key.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onhscroll">
        <!--13dcf63f-f6ce-4574-9dbc-6548554932e4-->
        <title>CWnd::OnHScroll</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the user clicks a window's horizontal scroll bar.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnHScroll(
    UINT nSBCode,
    UINT nPos,
    CScrollBar* pScrollBar );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nSBCode</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies a scroll-bar code that indicates the user's scrolling request. This parameter can be one of the following:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_LEFT</legacyBold>Scroll to far left.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_ENDSCROLL</legacyBold>End scroll.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_LINELEFT</legacyBold>Scroll left.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_LINERIGHT</legacyBold>Scroll right.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_PAGELEFT</legacyBold>Scroll one page left.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_PAGERIGHT</legacyBold>Scroll one page right.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_RIGHT</legacyBold>Scroll to far right.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_THUMBPOSITION</legacyBold>Scroll to absolute position. The current position is specified by the <parameterReference>nPos</parameterReference> parameter.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_THUMBTRACK</legacyBold>Drag scroll box to specified position. The current position is specified by the <parameterReference>nPos</parameterReference> parameter.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nPos</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the scroll-box position if the scroll-bar code is <legacyBold>SB_THUMBPOSITION</legacyBold> or <legacyBold>SB_THUMBTRACK</legacyBold>; otherwise, not used. Depending on the initial scroll range, <parameterReference>nPos</parameterReference> may be negative and should be cast to an <languageKeyword>int</languageKeyword> if necessary.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pScrollBar</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>If the scroll message came from a scroll-bar control, contains a pointer to the control. If the user clicked a window's scroll bar, this parameter is <legacyBold>NULL</legacyBold>. The pointer may be temporary and should not be stored for later use.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The <legacyBold>SB_THUMBTRACK</legacyBold> scroll-bar code typically is used by applications that give some feedback while the scroll box is being dragged. </para>
                    <para>If an application scrolls the contents controlled by the scroll bar, it must also reset the position of the scroll box with the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__setscrollpos">SetScrollPos</legacyLink> member function.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Example</title>
                <content>
                    <codeReference>NVC_MFCWindowing#108</codeReference>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onhscrollclipboard">
        <!--09033ab4-81bc-4f06-af45-844a77551f05-->
        <title>CWnd::OnHScrollClipboard</title>
        <content>
            <para>The Clipboard owner's <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnHScrollClipboard</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function is called by the Clipboard viewer when the Clipboard data has the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CF_OWNERDISPLAY</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> format and there is an event in the Clipboard viewer's horizontal scroll bar.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnHScrollClipboard(
    CWnd* pClipAppWnd,
    UINT nSBCode,
    UINT nPos );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pClipAppWnd</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies a pointer to a Clipboard-viewer window. The pointer may be temporary and should not be stored for later use.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nSBCode</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies one of the following scroll-bar codes in the low-order word:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_BOTTOM</legacyBold>Scroll to lower right.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_ENDSCROLL</legacyBold>End scroll.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_LINEDOWN</legacyBold>Scroll one line down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_LINEUP</legacyBold>Scroll one line up.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_PAGEDOWN</legacyBold>Scroll one page down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_PAGEUP</legacyBold>Scroll one page up.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_THUMBPOSITION</legacyBold>Scroll to the absolute position. The current position is provided in <parameterReference>nPos</parameterReference>.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SB_TOP</legacyBold>Scroll to upper left.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nPos</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Contains the scroll-box position if the scroll-bar code is <legacyBold>SB_THUMBPOSITION</legacyBold>; otherwise not used.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The owner should scroll the Clipboard image, invalidate the appropriate section, and update the scroll-bar values.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__oniconerasebkgnd">
        <!--af8933ce-18d4-4ee9-a48c-f60fc84f7d7f-->
        <title>CWnd::OnIconEraseBkgnd</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function for a minimized (iconic) <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object when the background of the icon must be filled before painting the icon.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnIconEraseBkgnd( CDC* pDC );</legacySyntax>
        </content>

            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pDC</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>

                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>

                    <para>The <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__defwindowproc">DefWindowProc</legacyLink> member function fills the icon background with the background brush of the parent window.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>

    <section address="cwnd__oninitmenu">
        <!--242e43eb-6b51-414f-be5a-9a4ffbd070dd-->
        <title>CWnd::OnInitMenu</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when a menu is about to become active.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnInitMenu( CMenu* pMenu );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pMenu</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the menu to be initialized. May be temporary and should not be stored for later use.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnInitMenu</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> is called when the user clicks an item on the menu bar or presses a menu key. Override this member function to modify the menu before it is displayed.</para>
                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnInitMenu</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> is only called once, when a menu is first accessed (for example, when a user clicks an item on the menu bar). This method does not provide information about menu items. As the user moves to items within the menu (for example, by moving the mouse across several menu items) the function is not called again. Once the user exits from the menu (for example, by clicking on the application client area) and later clicks an item on the menu bar, the function will be called again.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__oninitmenupopup">

        <title>CWnd::OnInitMenuPopup</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when a pop-up menu is about to become active.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnInitMenuPopup(
    CMenu* pPopupMenu,
    UINT nIndex,
    BOOL bSysMenu );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>

                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm>
                            <legacyItalic>pPopupMenu</legacyItalic>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the menu object of the pop-up menu. May be temporary and should not be stored for later use.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nIndex</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the index of the pop-up menu in the main menu.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm>

                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This allows an application to modify the pop-up menu before it is displayed without changing the entire menu.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>

                        </externalLink> notification, which is described in the <token>winSDK</token>. The is a generic input device message.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>

    <section address="cwnd__onkeydown">
        <!--cdd2592c-9f55-4696-8aca-7efe31b04011-->
        <title>CWnd::OnKeyDown</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when a nonsystem key is pressed.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnKeyDown(
    UINT nChar,
    UINT nRepCnt,
    UINT nFlags );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nChar</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the virtual key code of the given key. For a list of of standard virtual key codes, see Winuser.h</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nRepCnt</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Repeat count (the number of times the keystroke is repeated as a result of the user holding down the key).</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the scan code, key-transition code, previous key state, and context code, as shown in the following list:</para>
                            <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                                <thead>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Value</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Description</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                </thead>
                                <tbody>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>07</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Scan code (OEM-dependent value).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>8</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Extended key, such as a function key or a key on the numeric keypad (1 if it is an extended key).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>910</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Not used.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>1112</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Used internally by Windows.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>13</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Context code (1 if the ALT key is held down while the key is pressed; otherwise 0).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>14</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Previous key state (1 if the key is down before the call, 0 if the key is up).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>15</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Transition state (1 if the key is being released, 0 if the key is being pressed).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                </tbody>
                            </table>
                            <para>For a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_KEYDOWN</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message, the key-transition bit (bit 15) is 0 and the context-code bit (bit 13) is 0. </para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>A nonsystem key is a keyboard key that is pressed when the ALT key is not pressed or a keyboard key that is pressed when <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> has the input focus. </para>
                    <para>Because of auto-repeat, more than one <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnKeyDown</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> call may occur before an <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onkeyup">OnKeyUp</legacyLink> member function call is made. The bit that indicates the previous key state can be used to determine whether the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnKeyDown</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> call is the first down transition or a repeated down transition.</para>
                    <para>For IBM Enhanced 101- and 102-key keyboards, enhanced keys are the right ALT and the right CTRL keys on the main section of the keyboard; the INS, DEL, HOME, END, PAGE UP, PAGE DOWN, and arrow keys in the clusters to the left of the numeric keypad; and the slash (/) and ENTER keys in the numeric keypad. Some other keyboards may support the extended-key bit in <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onkeyup">
        <!--6bbca284-820c-4cd5-af6b-25da56e3e256-->
        <title>CWnd::OnKeyUp</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when a nonsystem key is released.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnKeyUp(
    UINT nChar,
    UINT nRepCnt,
    UINT nFlags );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nChar</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the virtual key code of the given key. For a list of of standard virtual key codes, see Winuser.h</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nRepCnt</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Repeat count (the number of times the keystroke is repeated as a result of the user holding down the key).</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the scan code, key-transition code, previous key state, and context code, as shown in the following list:</para>
                            <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                                <thead>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Value</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Description</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                </thead>
                                <tbody>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>07</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Scan code (OEM-dependent value). Low byte of high-order word.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>8</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Extended key, such as a function key or a key on the numeric keypad (1 if it is an extended key; otherwise 0).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>910</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Not used.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>1112</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Used internally by Windows.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>13</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Context code (1 if the ALT key is held down while the key is pressed; otherwise 0).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>14</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Previous key state (1 if the key is down before the call, 0 if the key is up).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>15</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Transition state (1 if the key is being released, 0 if the key is being pressed).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                </tbody>
                            </table>

        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function for the child window being deactivated and the child window being activated.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnMDIActivate(
    BOOL bActivate,
    CWnd* pActivateWnd,
    CWnd* pDeactivateWnd );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>bActivate</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para> <legacyBold>TRUE</legacyBold> if the child is being activated and <legacyBold>FALSE</legacyBold> if it is being deactivated.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pActivateWnd</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Contains a pointer to the MDI child window to be activated. When received by an MDI child window, <parameterReference>pActivateWnd</parameterReference> contains a pointer to the child window being activated. This pointer may be temporary and should not be stored for later use.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm>
                            <legacyItalic>pDeactivateWnd</legacyItalic>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Contains a pointer to the MDI child window being deactivated. This pointer may be temporary and should not be stored for later use.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>An MDI child window is activated independently of the MDI frame window. When the frame becomes active, the child window that was last activated with a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnMDIActivate</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> call receives an <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onncactivate">WM_NCACTIVATE</legacyLink> message to draw an active window frame and caption bar, but it does not receive another <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnMDIActivate</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> call.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>

    <section address="cwnd__onmeasureitem">
        <!--ba2f7e78-9998-4dda-8706-4d247d2a66ff-->
        <title>CWnd::OnMeasureItem</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function by the framework for the owner of an owner-draw button, combo box, list box, or menu item when the control is created.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnMeasureItem(
    int nIDCtl, LPMEASUREITEMSTRUCT lpMeasureItemStruct );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nIDCtl</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>The ID of the control.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>lpMeasureItemStruct</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Points to a <legacyLink xlink:href="d141ace4-47cb-46b5-a81c-ad2c5e5a8501">MEASUREITEMSTRUCT</legacyLink> data structure that contains the dimensions of the owner-draw control.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Override this member function and fill in the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>MEASUREITEMSTRUCT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> data structure pointed to by <parameterReference>lpMeasureItemStruct</parameterReference> and return; this informs Windows of the dimensions of the control and allows Windows to process user interaction with the control correctly.</para>
                    <para>If a list box or combo box is created with the <legacyLink xlink:href="3f357b8d-9118-4f41-9e28-02ed92d1e88f">LBS_OWNERDRAWVARIABLE</legacyLink> or <legacyLink xlink:href="d21a5023-e6a2-495b-a6bd-010a515cbc63">CBS_OWNERDRAWVARIABLE</legacyLink> style, the framework calls this function for the owner for each item in the control; otherwise this function is called once. </para>
                    <para>Windows initiates the call to <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnMeasureItem</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> for the owner of combo boxes and list boxes created with the <legacyBold>OWNERDRAWFIXED</legacyBold> style before sending the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_INITDIALOG</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms645428</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> message. As a result, when the owner receives this call, Windows has not yet determined the height and width of the font used in the control; function calls and calculations that require these values should occur in the main function of the application or library.</para>
                    <para>If the item being measured is a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CMenu</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CListBox</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> or <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CComboBox</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object, then the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>MeasureItem</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> virtual function of the appropriate class is called. Override the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>MeasureItem</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function of the appropriate control's class to calculate and set the size of each item.</para>
                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnMeasureItem</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> will be called only if the control's class is created at run time, or it is created with the <legacyBold>LBS_OWNERDRAWVARIABLE</legacyBold> or <legacyBold>CBS_OWNERDRAWVARIABLE</legacyBold> style. If the control is created by the dialog editor, <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnMeasureItem</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> will not be called. This is because the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_MEASUREITEM</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/bb775925</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> message is sent early in the creation process of the control. If you subclass by using <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>DDX_Control</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>SubclassDlgItem</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, or <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>SubclassWindow</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, the subclassing usually occurs after the creation process. Therefore, there is no way to handle the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_MEASUREITEM</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/bb775925</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> message in the control's <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnChildNotify</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> function, which is the mechanism MFC uses to implement <legacyBold>ON_WM_MEASUREITEM_REFLECT</legacyBold>.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
