                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nChar</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Depending on the build settings, specifies the ANSI or Unicode character that the user pressed.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Contains the <legacyBold>MF_POPUP</legacyBold> flag if the menu is a pop-up menu. It contains the <legacyBold>MF_SYSMENU</legacyBold> flag if the menu is a Control menu.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pMenu</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Contains a pointer to the selected <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CMenu</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>. The pointer may be temporary and should not be stored.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The high-order word of the return value should contain one of the following command codes:</para>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Value</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Description</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>0</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Tells Windows to discard the character that the user pressed and creates a short beep on the system speaker.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>1</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Tells Windows to close the current menu.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>2</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Informs Windows that the low-order word of the return value contains the item number for a specific item. This item is selected by Windows.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                    <para>The low-order word is ignored if the high-order word contains 0 or 1. Applications should process this message when accelerator (shortcut) keys are used to select bitmaps placed in a menu.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>It is sent to the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> that owns the menu. <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnMenuChar</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> is also called when the user presses ALT and any other key, even if the key does not correspond to a mnemonic character. In this case, <parameterReference>pMenu</parameterReference> points to the menu owned by the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, and <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference> is 0.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onmenudrag">
        <!--e1d53927-d5d2-439c-adcd-7f37fa2917ae-->
        <title>CWnd::OnMenuDrag</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function of the current drag-and-drop menu when the user begins to drag a menu item.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg UINT OnMenuDrag(
    UINT nPos, 
    CMenu* pMenu );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Parameter</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Description</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>nPos</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>The index position of the menu item when the drag operation begins.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>pMenu</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Pointer to the <legacyLink xlink:href="40cacfdc-d45c-4ec7-bf28-991c72812499">CMenu</legacyLink> object that contains the menu item.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Return Value</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Meaning</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para> <codeInline>MND_CONTINUE</codeInline>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>The menu should remain active. If the mouse is released, it should be ignored. </para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para> <codeInline>MND_ENDMENU</codeInline>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>The menu should be ended.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This method receives the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_MENUDRAG</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms647606</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> notification, which is described in the <token>winSDK</token>. </para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onmenugetobject">
        <!--10fc6f17-3e0b-42c7-aec8-7fbea029c428-->
        <title>CWnd::OnMenuGetObject</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function of the current drag-and-drop menu when the mouse cursor enters a menu item or moves from the center of the item to the top or bottom of the item.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg UINT OnMenuGetObject( MENUGETOBJECTINFO* pMenuGetObjectInfo );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Parameter</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Description</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>pMenu</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Pointer to a                                         <externalLink> <linkText>MENUGETOBJECTINFO</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms647572</linkUri>
                                        </externalLink> structure that contains information about the drag-and-drop menu the mouse cursor is on.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Return Value</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Meaning</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para> <codeInline>MNGO_NOERROR</codeInline>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>An interface pointer that supports drop-and-drag operations is returned in the <codeInline>pvObj</codeInline> member of the                                         <externalLink> <linkText>MENUGETOBJECTINFO</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms647572</linkUri>
                                        </externalLink> structure. Currently, only the                                         <externalLink> <linkText>IDropTarget</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms679679</linkUri>
                                        </externalLink> interface is supported. </para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para> <codeInline>MNGO_NOINTERFACE</codeInline>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>No drop-and-drag interface is supported.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This method receives the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_MENUGETOBJECT</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms647607</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> notification, which is described in the <token>winSDK</token>. </para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onmenurbuttonup">
        <!--f93da0dc-140f-4ba2-8408-e58519442727-->
        <title>CWnd::OnMenuRButtonUp</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the user releases the right mouse button while the cursor is on a menu item.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnMenuRButtonUp(
    UINT nPos,
    CMenu* pMenu );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Parameter</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Description</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>nPos</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>The index position of the menu item when the right mouse button was released.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>pMenu</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Pointer to the <legacyLink xlink:href="40cacfdc-d45c-4ec7-bf28-991c72812499">CMenu</legacyLink> object that contains the menu item.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This method receives the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_MENURBUTTONUP</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms647610</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> notification, which is described in the <token>winSDK</token>. The                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_MENURBUTTONUP</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms647610</linkUri>
                        </externalLink>message enablesan application to provide a context-sensitive menufor the menu item specified in the message. </para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>

        </sections>

    <section address="cwnd__onmenuselect">
        <!--8fff73f9-8987-409f-808f-6ae23667eeba-->
        <title>CWnd::OnMenuSelect</title>
        <content>
            <para>If the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object is associated with a menu, <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnMenuSelect</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> is called by the framework when the user selects a menu item.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnMenuSelect(
    UINT nItemID,
    UINT nFlags,
    HMENU hSysMenu );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nItemID</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Identifies the item selected. If the selected item is a menu item, <parameterReference>nItemID</parameterReference> contains the menu-item ID. If the selected item contains a pop-up menu, <parameterReference>nItemID</parameterReference> contains the pop-up menu index, and                                 <legacyItalic>hSysMenu </legacyItalic>contains the handle of the main (clicked-on) menu.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Contains a combination of the following menu flags:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MF_BITMAP</legacyBold>Item is a bitmap.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MF_CHECKED</legacyBold>Item is checked.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MF_DISABLED</legacyBold>Item is disabled.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MF_GRAYED</legacyBold>Item is dimmed.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MF_MOUSESELECT</legacyBold>Item was selected with a mouse.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>MF_OWNERDRAW</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>Item is an owner-draw item.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MF_POPUP</legacyBold>Item contains a pop-up menu.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MF_SEPARATOR</legacyBold>Item is a menu-item separator.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MF_SYSMENU</legacyBold>Item is contained in the Control menu.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>hSysMenu</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>If <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference> contains <legacyBold>MF_SYSMENU</legacyBold>, identifies the menu associated with the message. If <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference> contains <legacyBold>MF_POPUP</legacyBold>, identifies the handle of the main menu. If <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference> contains neither <legacyBold>MF_SYSMENU</legacyBold> nor <legacyBold>MF_POPUP</legacyBold>, it is unused.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>If <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference> contains 0xFFFF and <parameterReference>hSysMenu</parameterReference> contains 0, Windows has closed the menu because the user pressed the ESC key or clicked outside the menu.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onmouseactivate">
        <!--4343cede-c508-4624-94e3-35a2e178e950-->
        <title>CWnd::OnMouseActivate</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the cursor is in an inactive window and the user presses a mouse button.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg int OnMouseActivate(
    CWnd* pDesktopWnd,
    UINT nHitTest,
    UINT message );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm>
                            <legacyItalic>pDesktopWnd</legacyItalic>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies a pointer to the top-level parent window of the window being activated. The pointer may be temporary and should not be stored.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nHitTest</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onnchittest">hit-test</legacyLink> area code. A hit test is a test that determines the location of the cursor.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>message</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the mouse message number.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Specifies whether to activate the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> and whether to discard the mouse event. It must be one of the following values:  </para>
                    <list class="bullet">
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>MA_ACTIVATE</legacyBold>Activate <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>MA_NOACTIVATE</legacyBold>Do not activate <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>MA_ACTIVATEANDEAT</legacyBold>Activate <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object and discard the mouse event.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>MA_NOACTIVATEANDEAT</legacyBold>Do not activate <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object and discard the mouse event.</para>
                        </listItem>
                    </list>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The default implementation passes this message to the parent window before any processing occurs. If the parent window returns <legacyBold>TRUE</legacyBold>, processing is halted.</para>
                    <para>For a description of the individual hit-test area codes, see the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onnchittest">OnNcHitTest</legacyLink> member function</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Example</title>
                <content>
                    <codeReference>NVC_MFCAxCtl#9</codeReference>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onmousehover">
        <!--53495692-aa7b-4899-a753-829fadacaf4f-->
        <title>CWnd::OnMouseHover</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the cursor hovers over the client area of the window for the period of time specified in a prior call to                 <externalLink> <linkText>TrackMouseEvent</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms646265</linkUri>
                </externalLink>.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnMouseHover(
    UINT nFlags, 
    CPoint point );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Parameter</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Description</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>A bitwise combination (OR) of flags that indicate which modifier keys are pressed. For example, the <codeInline>MK_CONTROL</codeInline> flag indicates that the CTRL key is pressed. </para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>point</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>A <legacyLink xlink:href="a6d4db93-35cc-444d-9221-c3e160f6edaa">CPoint</legacyLink> object that specifies the                                         <placeholder>x</placeholder> and                                         <placeholder>y</placeholder> coordinates of the cursor relative to the upper-left corner of the client area.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This method receives the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_MOUSEHOVER</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms645613</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> notification, which is described in the <token>winSDK</token>.</para>
                    <para>The <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference> parameter can be a combination of modifier keys listed in the following table. For more information, see                         <externalLink> <linkText>About Mouse Input</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms645601</linkUri>
                        </externalLink>.</para>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Modifier Key</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Description</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>MK_CONTROL</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>The CTRL key is pressed.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>MK_LBUTTON</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>The left mouse button is pressed.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>MK_MBUTTON</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>The middle mouse button is pressed.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>MK_RBUTTON</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>The right mouse button is pressed.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>MK_SHIFT</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>The SHIFT key is pressed.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>MK_XBUTTON1</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>The XBUTTON1 mouse button of the Microsoft IntelliMouse is pressed.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>MK_XBUTTON2</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>The XBUTTON2 mouse button of the Microsoft IntelliMouse is pressed.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onmousehwheel">
        <!--11f05333-6065-4d1a-89db-d332e85926d4-->
        <title>CWnd::OnMouseHWheel</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member when the current window is composed by the Desktop Window Manager (DWM), and that window is maximized.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnMouseHWheel(
    UINT nFlags, 
    short zDelta, 
    CPoint pt );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Parameter</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Description</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>A bitwise combination (OR) of flags that indicate which modifier keys are pressed. For example, the <codeInline>MK_CONTROL</codeInline> flag indicates that the CTRL key is pressed.</para>
                                    <para>For a list of flags, see the "Message Parameters" subheading in                                         <externalLink> <linkText>About Mouse Input</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms645601</linkUri>
                                        </externalLink>.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>zDelta</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Indicates the distance the wheel is rotated, expressed in multiples or divisions of <codeInline>WHEEL_DELTA</codeInline>, which is 120. A positive value indicates that the wheel was rotated to the right; a negative value indicates that the wheel was rotated to the left.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>pt</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>A <legacyLink xlink:href="a6d4db93-35cc-444d-9221-c3e160f6edaa">CPoint</legacyLink> object that specifies the                                         <placeholder>x</placeholder> and                                         <placeholder>y</placeholder> coordinates of the cursor relative to the upper-left corner of the client area.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This method receives the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_MOUSEHWHEEL</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms645614</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> notification message, which is described in the <token>winSDK</token>. This message is sent to the window that has the focus when the mouse's horizontal scroll wheel is tilted or rotated.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>

    <section address="cwnd__onmousemove">
        <!--d7207f67-ca69-429b-85be-76dc34230624-->
        <title>CWnd::OnMouseMove</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the mouse cursor moves.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnMouseMove(
    UINT nFlags,
    CPoint point );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Indicates whether various virtual keys are down. This parameter can be any combination of the following values:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_CONTROL</legacyBold>Set if the CTRL key is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_LBUTTON</legacyBold>Set if the left mouse button is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_MBUTTON</legacyBold>Set if the middle mouse button is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_RBUTTON</legacyBold>Set if the right mouse button is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_SHIFT</legacyBold>Set if the SHIFT key is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>point</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the x- and y-coordinate of the cursor. These coordinates are always relative to the upper-left corner of the window.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>If the mouse is not captured, the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_MOUSEMOVE</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message is received by the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object beneath the mouse cursor; otherwise, the message goes to the window that has captured the mouse.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onmousewheel">
        <!--6cce8175-77a9-49cd-a150-5d68de2c28b0-->
        <title>CWnd::OnMouseWheel</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function as a user rotates the mouse wheel and encounters the wheel's next notch.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg BOOL OnMouseWheel(
    UINT nFlags,
    short zDelta,
    CPoint pt );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Indicates whether various virtual keys are down. This parameter can be any combination of the following values:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_CONTROL</legacyBold>Set if the CTRL key is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_LBUTTON</legacyBold>Set if the left mouse button is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_MBUTTON</legacyBold>Set if the middle mouse button is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_RBUTTON</legacyBold>Set if the right mouse button is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_SHIFT</legacyBold>Set if the SHIFT key is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>zDelta</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Indicates distance rotated. The <parameterReference>zDelta</parameterReference> value is expressed in multiples or divisions of <legacyBold>WHEEL_DELTA</legacyBold>, which is 120. A value less than zero indicates rotating back (toward the user) while a value greater than zero indicates rotating forward (away from the user). The user can reverse this response by changing the Wheel setting in the mouse software. See the Remarks for more information about this parameter.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pt</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the x- and y-coordinate of the cursor. These coordinates are always relative to the upper-left corner of the screen.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Nonzero if mouse wheel scrolling is enabled; otherwise 0.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Unless overridden, <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnMouseWheel</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> calls the default of                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_MOUSEWHEEL</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms645617</linkUri>
                        </externalLink>. Windows automatically routes the message to the control or child window that has the focus. The Win32 function                         <externalLink> <linkText>DefWindowProc</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms633572</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> propagates the message up the parent chain to the window that processes it.</para>
                    <para>The <parameterReference>zDelta</parameterReference> parameter is a multiple of <legacyBold>WHEEL_DELTA</legacyBold>, which is set at 120. This value is the threshold for an action to be taken, and one such action (for example, scrolling forward one notch) should occur for each delta. </para>
                    <para> <legacyBold>WHEEL_DELTA</legacyBold> was set to 120 to allow for finer-resolution wheels, such as a freely-rotating wheel with no notches. A finer-resolution wheel sends more messages per rotation, but each message has a smaller delta value. To use such a wheel, either add the incoming <parameterReference>zDelta</parameterReference> values until <legacyBold>WHEEL_DELTA</legacyBold> is reached (so that you get the same response for a given delta-rotation), or scroll partial lines in response to the more frequent messages. You can also choose a scroll granularity and accumulate deltas until <legacyBold>WHEEL_DELTA</legacyBold> is reached. </para>
                    <para>Override this member function to provide your own mouse-wheel scrolling behavior. </para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnMouseWheel</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> handles messages for Windows NT 4.0 and later versions. For Windows 95/98 or Windows NT 3.51 message handling, use <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onregisteredmousewheel">OnRegisteredMouseWheel</legacyLink>.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onmove">

    <section address="cwnd__onncactivate">

        <title>CWnd::OnNcActivate</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the nonclient area needs to be changed to indicate an active or inactive state.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg BOOL OnNcActivate( BOOL bActive );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>bActive</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies when a caption bar or icon needs to be changed to indicate an active or inactive state. The <parameterReference>bActive</parameterReference> parameter is <legacyBold>TRUE</legacyBold> if an active caption or icon is to be drawn. It is <legacyBold>FALSE</legacyBold> for an inactive caption or icon.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>

                    <para>Nonzero if Windows should proceed with default processing; 0 to prevent the caption bar or icon from being deactivated.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The default implementation draws the title bar and title-bar text in their active colors if <parameterReference>bActive</parameterReference> is <legacyBold>TRUE</legacyBold> and in their inactive colors if <parameterReference>bActive</parameterReference> is <legacyBold>FALSE</legacyBold>.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>

    <section address="cwnd__onnccalcsize">
        <!--5a2d7aef-3c83-4886-9824-df5309fdccad-->
        <title>CWnd::OnNcCalcSize</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the size and position of the client area needs to be calculated.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnNcCalcSize(
    BOOL bCalcValidRects,
    NCCALCSIZE_PARAMS* lpncsp );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>bCalcValidRects</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies whether the application should specify which part of the client area contains valid information. Windows will copy the valid information to the specified area within the new client area. If this parameter is <legacyBold>TRUE</legacyBold>, the application should specify which part of the client area is valid.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>lpncsp</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Points to a <legacyLink xlink:href="3424cd9f-806a-4089-82fb-414187589edf">NCCALCSIZE_PARAMS</legacyLink> data structure that contains information an application can use to calculate the new size and position of the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> rectangle (including client area, borders, caption, scroll bars, and so on).</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>By processing this message, an application can control the contents of the window's client area when the size or position of the window changes.</para>
                    <para>Regardless of the value of <parameterReference>bCalcValidRects</parameterReference>, the first rectangle in the array specified by the <legacyBold>rgrc</legacyBold> structure member of the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>NCCALCSIZE_PARAMS</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> structure contains the coordinates of the window. For a child window, the coordinates are relative to the parent window's client area. For top-level windows, the coordinates are screen coordinates. An application should modify the <legacyBold>rgrc[0]</legacyBold> rectangle to reflect the size and position of the client area. </para>
                    <para>The <legacyBold>rgrc[1]</legacyBold> and <legacyBold>rgrc[2]</legacyBold> rectangles are valid only if <parameterReference>bCalcValidRects</parameterReference> is <legacyBold>TRUE</legacyBold>. In this case, the <legacyBold>rgrc[1]</legacyBold> rectangle contains the coordinates of the window before it was moved or resized. The <legacyBold>rgrc[2]</legacyBold> rectangle contains the coordinates of the window's client area before the window was moved. All coordinates are relative to the parent window or screen.</para>
                    <para>The default implementation calculates the size of the client area based on the window characteristics (presence of scroll bars, menu, and so on), and places the result in <parameterReference>lpncsp</parameterReference>.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>

        <title>CWnd::OnNcDestroy</title>
        <content>

        </content>

                <content>
                    <para>The default implementation performs some cleanup, then calls the virtual member function <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__postncdestroy">PostNcDestroy</legacyLink>. </para>
                    <para>Override <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PostNcDestroy</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> if you want to perform your own cleanup, such as a <legacyBold>delete this</legacyBold> operation. If you override <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnNcDestroy</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, you must call <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnNcDestroy</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> in your base class to ensure that any memory internally allocated for the window is freed.</para>

    <section address="cwnd__onnclbuttondblclk">
        <!--2afb19d0-a0da-41b0-b244-d8f739985c57-->
        <title>CWnd::OnNcLButtonDblClk</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the user double-clicks the left mouse button while the cursor is within a nonclient area of <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnNcLButtonDblClk(
    UINT nHitTest,
    CPoint point );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nHitTest</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onnchittest">hit-test code</legacyLink>. A hit test is a test that determines the location of the cursor.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>point</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CPoint</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object that contains the x and y screen coordinates of the cursor position. These coordinates are always relative to the upper-left corner of the screen.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>

                        </externalLink> notification, which is described in the <token>winSDK</token>. This message is posted to the window that contains the cursor. If a window has captured the mouse, this message is not posted.</para>
