    <section address="cwnd__onnotify">
        <!--fb4687ed-4198-4e7c-9ace-caf87d1e7cb6-->
        <title>CWnd::OnNotify</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function to inform the parent window of a control that an event has occurred in the control or that the control requires some kind of information.</para>
            <legacySyntax>virtual BOOL OnNotify(
    WPARAM wParam,
    LPARAM lParam,
    LRESULT* pResult );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>wParam</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Identifies the control that sends the message if the message is from a control. Otherwise, <parameterReference>wParam</parameterReference> is 0.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>lParam</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Pointer to a notification message ( <legacyBold>NMHDR</legacyBold>) structure that contains the notification code and additional information. For some notification messages, this parameter points to a larger structure that has the <legacyBold>NMHDR</legacyBold> structure as its first member.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pResult</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Pointer to an <legacyBold>LRESULT</legacyBold> variable in which to store the result code if the message is handled.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>An application returns nonzero if it processes this message; otherwise 0.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnNotify</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> processes the message map for control notification.</para>
                    <para>Override this member function in your derived class to handle the <legacyBold>WM_NOTIFY</legacyBold> message. An override will not process the message map unless the base class <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnNotify</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> is called.</para>
                    <para>For more information on the WM_NOTIFY message, see Technical Note 61 (TN061), <legacyLink xlink:href="04a96dde-7049-41df-9954-ad7bb5587caf">ON_NOTIFY and WM_NOTIFY messages</legacyLink>. You may also be interested the related topics described in <legacyLink xlink:href="b2842884-6435-4b8f-933b-21671bf8af95">Control Topics</legacyLink>, and TN062, <legacyLink xlink:href="53efb0ba-fcda-4fa0-a3c7-14e0b78fb494">Message Reflection for Windows Controls</legacyLink>.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onnotifyformat">
        <!--09289222-ce3f-48fc-b3c9-b7f22873b9e8-->
        <title>CWnd::OnNotifyFormat</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function to determine if the current window accepts ANSI or Unicode structures in the WM_NOTIFY notification message.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg UINT OnNotifyFormat(
    CWnd* pWnd, 
    UINT nCommand );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Parameter</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Description</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>pWnd</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>A pointer to a <legacyLink xlink:href="49a832ee-bc34-4126-88b3-bc1d9974f6c4">CWnd</legacyLink> object that represents the window sending the                                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_NOTIFY</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/bb775583</linkUri>
                                        </externalLink> message. </para>
                                    <para>This parameter is the pointer to a control if the <parameterReference>nCommand</parameterReference> parameter is <codeInline>NF_QUERY</codeInline>, or the pointer to the parent window of a control if <parameterReference>nCommand</parameterReference> is <codeInline>NF_REQUERY</codeInline>.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>nCommand</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>A command value that specializes the                                         <system>WM_NOTIFY</system> message. The possible values are: </para>
                                    <list class="bullet">
                                        <listItem>
                                            <para> <codeInline>NF_QUERY</codeInline> - </para>
                                            <para>The message is a query to determine whether ANSI or Unicode structures should be used in                                                 <system>WM_NOTIFY</system> messages. This message is sent from a control to its parent window during the creation of a control, and in response to the <codeInline>NF_REQUERY</codeInline> form of this message.</para>
                                        </listItem>
                                        <listItem>
                                            <para> <codeInline>NF_REQUERY</codeInline> - </para>
                                            <para>The message is a request for a control to send the <codeInline>NF_QUERY</codeInline> form of this message to its parent window. This request is sent from the parent window, and asks the control to requery the parent about the type of structure to use in                                                 <system>WM_NOTIFY</system> messages. If the <parameterReference>nCommand</parameterReference> parameter is <codeInline>NF_REQUERY</codeInline>, the return value is the result of the requery operation.</para>
                                        </listItem>
                                    </list>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Return value</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Meaning</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para> <codeInline>NFR_ANSI</codeInline>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>ANSI structures should be used in                                         <system>WM_NOTIFY</system> messages sent by the control. </para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para> <codeInline>NFR_UNICODE</codeInline>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Unicode structures should be used in                                         <system>WM_NOTIFY</system> messages sent by the control.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>0</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>An error occurred.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This method receives the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_NOTIFYFORMAT</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/bb775584</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> notification, which is described in the <token>winSDK</token>.                         <system>WM_NOTIFY</system>messages are sent from a common control to its parent window, and from the parent window to the common control.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onpaint">
        <!--eb3b1ad8-2183-42ca-a0e6-64d8667a88c8-->
        <title>CWnd::OnPaint</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when Windows or an application makes a request to repaint a portion of an application's window.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnPaint();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_PAINT</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd145137</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> message is sent when the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__updatewindow">UpdateWindow</legacyLink> or <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__redrawwindow">RedrawWindow</legacyLink> member function is called.</para>
                    <para>A window may receive internal paint messages as a result of calling the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>RedrawWindow</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function with the <legacyBold>RDW_INTERNALPAINT</legacyBold> flag set. In this case, the window may not have an update region. An application should call the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__getupdaterect">GetUpdateRect</legacyLink> member function to determine whether the window has an update region. If <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>GetUpdateRect</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> returns 0, the application should not call the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__beginpaint">BeginPaint</legacyLink> and <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__endpaint">EndPaint</legacyLink> member functions.</para>
                    <para>It is an application's responsibility to check for any necessary internal repainting or updating by looking at its internal data structures for each <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_PAINT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message because a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_PAINT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message may have been caused by both an invalid area and a call to the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>RedrawWindow</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function with the <legacyBold>RDW_INTERNALPAINT</legacyBold> flag set. </para>
                    <para>An internal <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_PAINT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message is sent only once by Windows. After an internal <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_PAINT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message is sent to a window by the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>UpdateWindow</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function, no further <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_PAINT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> messages will be sent or posted until the window is invalidated or until the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>RedrawWindow</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function is called again with the <legacyBold>RDW_INTERNALPAINT</legacyBold> flag set.</para>
                    <para>For information on rendering an image in document/view applications, see <legacyLink xlink:href="9cff3c56-7564-416b-b9a4-71a9254ed755#cview__ondraw">CView::OnDraw</legacyLink>.</para>
                    <para>For more information about using <legacyBold>WM_Paint</legacyBold>, see the following topics in the <token>winSDK</token>:  </para>
                    <list class="bullet">
                        <listItem>
                            <para>
                                <externalLink> <linkText>The WM_PAINT Message</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd145137</linkUri>
                                </externalLink>
                            </para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para>
                                <externalLink> <linkText>Using the WM_PAINT Message</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd145193</linkUri>
                                </externalLink>
                            </para>
                        </listItem>
                    </list>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onpaintclipboard">
        <!--6f9bcf0e-04e6-4a24-b0f6-baae4617998f-->
        <title>CWnd::OnPaintClipboard</title>
        <content>
            <para>A Clipboard owner's <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnPaintClipboard</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function is called by a Clipboard viewer when the Clipboard owner has placed data on the Clipboard in the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CF_OWNERDISPLAY</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> format and the Clipboard viewer's client area needs repainting.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnPaintClipboard(
    CWnd* pClipAppWnd,
    HGLOBAL hPaintStruct );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pClipAppWnd</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies a pointer to the Clipboard-application window. The pointer may be temporary and should not be stored for later use.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm>
                            <legacyItalic>hPaintStruct</legacyItalic>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Identifies a <legacyLink xlink:href="81ce4993-3e89-43b2-8c98-7946f1314d24">PAINTSTRUCT</legacyLink> data structure that defines what part of the client area to paint.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>To determine whether the entire client area or just a portion of it needs repainting, the Clipboard owner must compare the dimensions of the drawing area given in the <legacyBold>rcpaint</legacyBold> member of the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PAINTSTRUCT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> structure to the dimensions given in the most recent <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onsizeclipboard">OnSizeClipboard</legacyLink> member function call.</para>
                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnPaintClipboard</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> should use the                         <externalLink> <linkText>GlobalLock</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa366584</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function to lock the memory that contains the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>PAINTSTRUCT</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> data structure and unlock that memory with the                         <externalLink> <linkText>GlobalUnlock</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa366595</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function before it exits.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onpalettechanged">
        <!--1ebfc90b-65b9-42b2-b7fb-dd9a57667558-->
        <title>CWnd::OnPaletteChanged</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function for all top-level windows after the window with input focus has realized its logical palette, thereby changing the system palette.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnPaletteChanged( CWnd* pFocusWnd );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pFocusWnd</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies a pointer to the window that caused the system palette to change. The pointer may be temporary and should not be stored.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This call allows a window without the input focus that uses a color palette to realize its logical palettes and update its client area. </para>
                    <para>The <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnPaletteChanged</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function is called for all top-level and overlapped windows, including the one that changed the system palette and caused the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_PALETTECHANGED</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message to be sent. If any child window uses a color palette, this message must be passed on to it. </para>
                    <para>To avoid an infinite loop, the window shouldn't realize its palette unless it determines that <parameterReference>pFocusWnd</parameterReference> does not contain a pointer to itself.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onpaletteischanging">
        <!--4beef7f5-a575-4c79-83cd-66c6f816e00f-->
        <title>CWnd::OnPaletteIsChanging</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function to inform applications that an application is going to realize its logical palette.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnPaletteIsChanging( CWnd* pRealizeWnd );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm>
                            <legacyItalic>pRealizeWnd</legacyItalic>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the window that is about to realize its logical palette.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onparentnotify">
        <!--de628c78-460f-4c3b-81e4-cee21fdb5190-->
        <title>CWnd::OnParentNotify</title>
        <content>
            <para>A parent's <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnParentNotify</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function is called by the framework when its child window is created or destroyed, or when the user clicks a mouse button while the cursor is over the child window.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnParentNotify(
    UINT message,
    LPARAM lParam );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>message</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the event for which the parent is being notified and the identifier of the child window. The event is the low-order word of <parameterReference>message</parameterReference>. If the event is <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_CREATE</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> or <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_DESTROY</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, the high-order word of <parameterReference>message</parameterReference> is the identifier of the child window; otherwise, the high-order word is undefined. The event (low-order word of <parameterReference>message</parameterReference>) can be any of these values:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_CREATE</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>The child window is being created.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_DESTROY</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>The child window is being destroyed.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_LBUTTONDOWN</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>The user has placed the mouse cursor over the child window and clicked the left mouse button.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_MBUTTONDOWN</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>The user has placed the mouse cursor over the child window and clicked the middle mouse button.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_RBUTTONDOWN</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>The user has placed the mouse cursor over the child window and clicked the right mouse button.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>lParam</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>If the event (low-order word) of <parameterReference>message</parameterReference> is <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_CREATE</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> or <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_DESTROY</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, <parameterReference>lParam</parameterReference> specifies the window handle of the child window; otherwise <parameterReference>lParam</parameterReference> contains the x and y coordinates of the cursor. The x coordinate is in the low-order word and the y coordinate is in the high-order word.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>When the child window is being created, the system calls <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnParentNotify</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> just before the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__create">Create</legacyLink> member function that creates the window returns. When the child window is being destroyed, the system calls <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnParentNotify</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> before any processing takes place to destroy the window. </para>
                    <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnParentNotify</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> is called for all ancestor windows of the child window, including the top-level window.</para>
                    <para>All child windows except those that have the <legacyLink xlink:href="d18e6c69-0a01-49ed-b58a-55b3802b47c1">WS_EX_NOPARENTNOTIFY</legacyLink> style send this message to their parent windows. By default, child windows in a dialog box have the <legacyBold>WS_EX_NOPARENTNOTIFY</legacyBold> style unless the child window was created without this style by calling the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__createex">CreateEx</legacyLink> member function. </para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onpowerbroadcast">
        <!--e5a79a17-1aeb-41f8-9e06-76e8f4223b99-->
        <title>CWnd::OnPowerBroadcast</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when a power-management event occurs.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg UINT OnPowerBroadcast(
    UINT nPowerEvent, 
    UINT nEventData );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Parameter</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Description</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>nPowerEvent</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>The power-management event.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>nEventData</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Event-specific data.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>If the event is a request, return <codeInline>true</codeInline> to grant the request, or <codeInline>BROADCAST_QUERY_DENY</codeInline> to deny the request.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This method receives the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_POWERBROADCAST</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa373247</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> message, which is described in the <token>winSDK</token>. </para>
                    <para>The <parameterReference>nPowerEvent</parameterReference> parameter specifies events such as battery power is low, the power status has changed, permission to suspend operation is requested or denied, an operation is resuming automatically after an event, the system is suspending operation, or an operation is resuming after suspension. The <parameterReference>nEventData</parameterReference> parameter is typically not used. For more information, see the <codeInline>wParam</codeInline> and <codeInline>lParam</codeInline> parameters of the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_POWERBROADCAST</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa373247</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> message.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onquerydragicon">
        <!--47b18fa3-6a45-4081-9def-b024badafb5a-->
        <title>CWnd::OnQueryDragIcon</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function by a minimized (iconic) window that does not have an icon defined for its class.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg HCURSOR OnQueryDragIcon();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>A doubleword value that contains a cursor or icon handle in the low-order word. The cursor or icon must be compatible with the display driver's resolution. If the application returns <legacyBold>NULL</legacyBold>, the system displays the default cursor. The default return value is <legacyBold>NULL</legacyBold>.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The system makes this call to obtain the cursor to display while the user drags the minimized window. If an application returns the handle of an icon or cursor, the system converts it to black-and-white. If an application returns a handle, the handle must identify a monochrome cursor or icon compatible with the display driver's resolution. The application can call the <legacyLink xlink:href="e426a3cd-0d15-40d6-bd55-beaa5feb2343#cwinapp__loadcursor">CWinApp::LoadCursor</legacyLink> or <legacyLink xlink:href="e426a3cd-0d15-40d6-bd55-beaa5feb2343#cwinapp__loadicon">CWinApp::LoadIcon</legacyLink> member functions to load a cursor or icon from the resources in its executable file and to obtain this handle.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onqueryendsession">
        <!--b0256bc8-ef85-4647-a30d-1c3a1e3d6481-->
        <title>CWnd::OnQueryEndSession</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the user chooses to end the Windows session or when an application calls the                 <externalLink> <linkText>ExitWindows</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa376867</linkUri>
                </externalLink> Windows function.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg BOOL OnQueryEndSession();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Nonzero if an application can be conveniently shut down; otherwise 0.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>If any application returns 0, the Windows session is not ended. Windows stops calling <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnQueryEndSession</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> as soon as one application returns 0 and sends the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onendsession">WM_ENDSESSION</legacyLink> message with a parameter value of <legacyBold>FALSE</legacyBold> for any application that has already returned nonzero.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onquerynewpalette">
        <!--3bbf0a2d-9004-4298-b781-e1bb74f7eb0a-->
        <title>CWnd::OnQueryNewPalette</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object is about to receive the input focus, giving the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> an opportunity to realize its logical palette when it receives the focus.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg BOOL OnQueryNewPalette();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Nonzero if the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> realizes its logical palette; otherwise 0.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onqueryopen">
        <!--b00da448-2d9d-4ad7-bf98-0e1565d81e21-->
        <title>CWnd::OnQueryOpen</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object is minimized and the user requests that the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> be restored to its preminimized size and position.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg BOOL OnQueryOpen();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Nonzero if the icon can be opened, or 0 to prevent the icon from being opened.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>While in <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnQueryOpen</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> should not perform any action that would cause an activation or focus change (for example, creating a dialog box).</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onqueryuistate">
        <!--09c74433-4825-468c-81ca-d44df7fdc0ac-->
        <title>CWnd::OnQueryUIState</title>
        <content>
            <para>Called to retrieve the user interface (UI) state for a window.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg UINT OnQueryUIState();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The return value is <legacyBold>NULL</legacyBold> if the focus indicators and the keyboard accelerators are visible. Otherwise, the return value can be one or more of the following values:  </para>
                    <list class="bullet">
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>UISF_HIDEFOCUS</legacyBold>Focus indicators are hidden.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>UISF_HIDEACCEL</legacyBold>Keyboard accelerators are hidden.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para> <legacyBold>UISF_ACTIVE</legacyBold> <legacyBold>Windows XP:</legacyBold> A control should be drawn in the style used for active controls.</para>
                        </listItem>
                    </list>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This member function emulates the functionality of the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_QUERYUISTATE</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms646355</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> message, as described in the <token>winSDK</token>.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onrawinput">
        <!--ddb52793-af9c-4492-a7e9-5cff94074883-->
        <title>CWnd::OnRawInput</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the current window gets raw input.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnRawInput(
    UINT nInputCode,
    HRAWINPUT hRawInput );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Parameter</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Description</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>nInputCode</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Input code that indicates whether the input occurred while the application was in the foreground or not. In either case, the application must call <link xlink:href="#cwnd__defwindowproc">CWnd::DefWindowProc</link> so the system can perform cleanup. </para>
                                    <para>This parameter can be one of the following values:</para>
                                    <list class="bullet">
                                        <listItem>
                                            <para> <codeInline>RIM_INPUT</codeInline> - Input occurred while the application was in the foreground. </para>
                                        </listItem>
                                        <listItem>
                                            <para> <codeInline>RIM_INPUTSINK</codeInline> - Input occurred while the application was not in the foreground. </para>
                                        </listItem>
                                    </list>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>hRawInput</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Handle to a                                         <externalLink> <linkText>RAWINPUT</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms645562</linkUri>
                                        </externalLink> structure that contains the raw input from the device.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This method receives the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_INPUT</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms646275</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> notification, which is described in the <token>winSDK</token>. </para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onrbuttondblclk">
        <!--00631032-29a7-4e74-b239-b9ce7fbf3a31-->
        <title>CWnd::OnRButtonDblClk</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the user double-clicks the right mouse button.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnRButtonDblClk(
    UINT nFlags,
    CPoint point );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Indicates whether various virtual keys are down. This parameter can be any combination of the following values:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_CONTROL</legacyBold>Set if CTRL key is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_LBUTTON</legacyBold>Set if left mouse button is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_MBUTTON</legacyBold>Set if middle mouse button is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_RBUTTON</legacyBold>Set if right mouse button is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_SHIFT</legacyBold>Set if SHIFT key is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>point</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the x and y coordinates of the cursor. These coordinates are always relative to the upper-left corner of the window.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Only windows that have the <legacyBold>CS_DBLCLKS</legacyBold>                        <externalLink> <linkText>WNDCLASS</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms633576</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> style can receive <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnRButtonDblClk</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> calls. This is the default for windows within the Microsoft Foundation Class Library. Windows calls <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnRButtonDblClk</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> when the user presses, releases, and then again presses the right mouse button within the system's double-click time limit. Double-clicking the right mouse button actually generates four events: <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onrbuttondown">WM_RBUTTONDOWN</legacyLink> and <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onrbuttonup">WM_RBUTTONUP</legacyLink> messages, the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnRButtonDblClk</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> call, and another <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_RBUTTONUP</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message when the button is released.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onrbuttondown">
        <!--ea3887ba-2520-48af-a104-8256cb899d28-->

        <sections>

                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Indicates whether various virtual keys are down. This parameter can be any combination of the following values:</para>

                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_CONTROL</legacyBold>Set if CTRL key is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_LBUTTON</legacyBold>Set if left mouse button is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_MBUTTON</legacyBold>Set if middle mouse button is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_RBUTTON</legacyBold>Set if right mouse button is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_SHIFT</legacyBold>Set if SHIFT key is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>point</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the x and y coordinates of the cursor. These coordinates are always relative to the upper-left corner of the window.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onrbuttonup">
        <!--0cb0fc44-849b-4207-9f9b-fecb2c58c78b-->
        <title>CWnd::OnRButtonUp</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the user releases the right mouse button.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnRButtonUp(
    UINT nFlags,
    CPoint point );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Indicates whether various virtual keys are down. This parameter can be any combination of the following values:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_CONTROL</legacyBold>Set if CTRL key is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_LBUTTON</legacyBold>Set if left mouse button is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_MBUTTON</legacyBold>Set if middle mouse button is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>MK_SHIFT</legacyBold>Set if SHIFT key is down.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>point</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the x and y coordinates of the cursor. These coordinates are always relative to the upper-left corner of the window.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onregisteredmousewheel">
        <!--592d66c5-2320-4206-89fc-3e959156c491-->
        <title>CWnd::OnRegisteredMouseWheel</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function as a user rotates the mouse wheel and encounters the wheel's next notch.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg LRESULT OnRegisteredMouseWheel(
    WPARAM wParam,
    LPARAM lParam );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>wParam</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Horizontal position of the pointer.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>lParam</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Vertical position of the pointer.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Insignificant at this time. Always zero.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Unless overridden, <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnRegisteredMouseWheel</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> routes the message to the appropriate window (the parent window with focus), and calls the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_MOUSEWHEEL</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms645617</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> handler for that window.</para>
                    <para>Override this member function to provide your own message routing or to alter the mouse-wheel scrolling behavior.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para> <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnRegisteredMouseWheel</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> handles messages for Windows 95/98 and Windows NT 3.51. For Windows NT 4.0 message handling, use <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onmousewheel">OnMouseWheel</legacyLink>.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onrenderallformats">
        <!--1d19453f-9a68-488e-851d-bbefb52d709c-->
        <title>CWnd::OnRenderAllFormats</title>
        <content>
            <para>The Clipboard owner's <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnRenderAllFormats</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function is called by the framework when the owner application is being destroyed.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnRenderAllFormats();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The Clipboard owner should render the data in all the formats it is capable of generating and pass a data handle for each format to the Clipboard by calling the                         <externalLink> <linkText>SetClipboardData</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms649051</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function. This ensures that the Clipboard contains valid data even though the application that rendered the data is destroyed. The application should call the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__openclipboard">OpenClipboard</legacyLink> member function before calling the                         <externalLink> <linkText>SetClipboardData</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms649051</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function and call the                         <externalLink> <linkText>CloseClipboard</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms649035</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function afterward.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onrenderformat">
        <!--48a79f20-514d-4a4d-b83d-33c4945d76ce-->
        <title>CWnd::OnRenderFormat</title>
        <content>
            <para>The Clipboard owner's <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnRenderFormat</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function is called by the framework when a particular format with delayed rendering needs to be rendered.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnRenderFormat( UINT nFormat );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nFormat</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the Clipboard format.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The receiver should render the data in that format and pass it to the Clipboard by calling the                         <externalLink> <linkText>SetClipboardData</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms649051</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function. </para>
                    <para>Do not call the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OpenClipboard</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function or the <legacyBold>CloseClipboard</legacyBold> Windows function from within <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnRenderFormat</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onsessionchange">
        <!--8a7567e5-112f-4248-b4b4-5dc3fdf75aad-->
        <title>CWnd::OnSessionChange</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function to notify an application of a change in session state.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnSessionChange(
    UINT nSessionState, 
    UINT nId );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Parameter</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Description</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>nSessionState</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>A status code describes the session state change.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>[in] <parameterReference>nId</parameterReference>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>A session identifier.</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This method receives the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_WTSSESSION_CHANGE</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/aa383828</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> notification, which is described in the <token>winSDK</token>. </para>
                    <para>The <parameterReference>nSessionState</parameterReference> parameter specifies that a session is connected or disconnected from the console or a remote terminal, a user logged on or off, a session is locked or unlocked, or a session has changed to remote-controlled status. For more information, see the <codeInline>wParam</codeInline> parameter of the the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_WTSSESSION_CHANGE</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/aa383828</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> message.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onsetcursor">
        <!--72898ddb-9d5f-4277-9023-6dad34bf24b6-->
        <title>CWnd::OnSetCursor</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function if mouse input is not captured and the mouse causes cursor movement within the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg BOOL OnSetCursor(
    CWnd* pWnd,
    UINT nHitTest,
    UINT message );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pWnd</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies a pointer to the window that contains the cursor. The pointer may be temporary and should not be stored for later use.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nHitTest</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onnchittest">hit-test</legacyLink> area code. The hit test determines the cursor's location.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>message</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the mouse message number.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Nonzero to halt further processing, or 0 to continue.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The default implementation calls the parent window's <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSetCursor</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> before processing. If the parent window returns <legacyBold>TRUE</legacyBold>, further processing is halted. Calling the parent window gives the parent window control over the cursor's setting in a child window. </para>
                    <para>The default implementation sets the cursor to an arrow if it is not in the client area or to the registered-class cursor if it is.</para>
                    <para>If <parameterReference>nHitTest</parameterReference> is <legacyBold>HTERROR</legacyBold> and <parameterReference>message</parameterReference> is a mouse button-down message, the <legacyBold>MessageBeep</legacyBold> member function is called. </para>
                    <para>The <parameterReference>message</parameterReference> parameter is 0 when <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> enters menu mode.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onsetfocus">
        <!--f0b362a1-7a7c-4b41-aaae-7c7bfebda967-->
        <title>CWnd::OnSetFocus</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function after gaining the input focus.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnSetFocus( CWnd* pOldWnd );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm>
                            <legacyItalic>pOldWnd</legacyItalic>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Contains the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object that loses the input focus (may be <legacyBold>NULL</legacyBold>). The pointer may be temporary and should not be stored for later use.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>To display a caret, <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> should call the appropriate caret functions at this point.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onsettingchange">
        <!--91392ea8-e411-4660-a77b-7488db5fa060-->
        <title>CWnd::OnSettingChange</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSettingChange</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> for all top-level windows when the Win32 SystemParametersInfo function changes a system-wide setting.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnSettingChange(
    UINT uFlags,
    LPCTSTR lpszSection );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>uFlags</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>When the system sends the message as a result of a <legacyBold>SystemParametersInfo</legacyBold> call, this parameter is a flag that indicates the system parameter that was changed. For a list of values, see                                 <externalLink> <linkText>SystemParametersInfo</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms724947</linkUri>
                                </externalLink> in the <token>winSDK</token>. When an application sends the message, this parameter must be 0.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>lpszSection</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Points to a string that specifies the name of the section that has changed. (The string does not include the square brackets that enclose the section name.)</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>An application should send the message to all top-level windows when it makes changes to system parameters, and Windows will send the message if the user changes settings via the Control Panel.</para>
                    <para>The <legacyBold>ON_WM_SETTINGCHANGE</legacyBold> message is similar to the <legacyBold>ON_WM_WININICHANGE</legacyBold> message, with the following difference:  </para>
                    <list class="bullet">
                        <listItem>
                            <para>Use <legacyBold>ON_WM_SETTINGCHANGE</legacyBold> when running Windows NT 4.0 or newer, or under Windows 95/98.</para>
                        </listItem>
                        <listItem>
                            <para>Use <legacyBold>ON_WININICHANGE</legacyBold> when running Windows NT 3.51 or older. This message is now obsolete.</para>
                        </listItem>
                    </list>
                    <para>You should have only one of these macros in your message map. To write a program that works for both Windows 95/98 and Windows NT 4.0, write a handler for <legacyBold>ON_WM_SETTINGCHANGE</legacyBold>. Under Windows NT 3.51, your handler will be called by <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSettingChange</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> and <parameterReference>uFlags</parameterReference> and will always be zero.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onshowwindow">
        <!--21896315-1b23-455c-8e79-8eb9240ec9b5-->
        <title>CWnd::OnShowWindow</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object is about to be hidden or shown.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnShowWindow(
    BOOL bShow,
    UINT nStatus );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>bShow</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies whether a window is being shown. It is <legacyBold>TRUE</legacyBold> if the window is being shown; it is <legacyBold>FALSE</legacyBold> if the window is being hidden.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nStatus</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the status of the window being shown. It is 0 if the message is sent because of a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>ShowWindow</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function call; otherwise <parameterReference>nStatus</parameterReference> is one of the following:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SW_PARENTCLOSING</legacyBold>Parent window is closing (being made iconic) or a pop-up window is being hidden.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SW_PARENTOPENING</legacyBold>Parent window is opening (being displayed) or a pop-up window is being shown.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>A window is hidden or shown when the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>ShowWindow</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function is called, when an overlapped window is maximized or restored, or when an overlapped or pop-up window is closed (made iconic) or opened (displayed on the screen). When an overlapped window is closed, all pop-up windows associated with that window are hidden.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onsize">
        <!--b10298b1-b1fe-4db0-8ac2-ca603aa1e8a4-->
        <title>CWnd::OnSize</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function after the window's size has changed.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnSize(
    UINT nType,
    int cx,
    int cy );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nType</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the type of resizing requested. This parameter can be one of the following values:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SIZE_MAXIMIZED</legacyBold>Window has been maximized.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SIZE_MINIMIZED</legacyBold>Window has been minimized.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SIZE_RESTORED</legacyBold>Window has been resized, but neither <legacyBold>SIZE_MINIMIZED</legacyBold> nor <legacyBold>SIZE_MAXIMIZED</legacyBold> applies.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SIZE_MAXHIDE</legacyBold>Message is sent to all pop-up windows when some other window is maximized.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
