                                    <para> <legacyBold>SIZE_MAXSHOW</legacyBold>Message is sent to all pop-up windows when some other window has been restored to its former size.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>cx</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the new width of the client area.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>cy</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the new height of the client area.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>If the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__setscrollpos">SetScrollPos</legacyLink> or <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__movewindow">MoveWindow</legacyLink> member function is called for a child window from <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSize</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, the <parameterReference>bRedraw</parameterReference> parameter of <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>SetScrollPos</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> or <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>MoveWindow</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> should be nonzero to cause the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> to be repainted.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Example</title>
                <content>
                    <codeReference>NVC_MFCWindowing#109</codeReference>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onsizeclipboard">
        <!--c816a33c-f7fa-48c5-948d-700c0db3a425-->
        <title>CWnd::OnSizeClipboard</title>
        <content>
            <para>The Clipboard owner's <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSizeClipboard</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function is called by the Clipboard viewer when the Clipboard contains data with the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CF_OWNERDISPLAY</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> attribute and the size of the client area of the Clipboard-viewer window has changed.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnSizeClipboard(
    CWnd* pClipAppWnd,
    HGLOBAL hRect );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pClipAppWnd</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Identifies the Clipboard-application window. The pointer may be temporary and should not be stored.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm>
                            <legacyItalic>hRect</legacyItalic>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Identifies a global memory object. The memory object contains a <legacyLink xlink:href="1b3160de-64e9-40d1-89eb-af3e0fd6acf0">RECT</legacyLink> data structure that specifies the area for the Clipboard owner to paint.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSizeClipboard</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function is called with a null rectangle (0,0,0,0) as the new size when the Clipboard application is about to be destroyed or minimized. This permits the Clipboard owner to free its display resources. </para>
                    <para>Within <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSizeClipboard</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, an application must use the                         <externalLink> <linkText>GlobalLock</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa366584</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function to lock the memory that contains the <legacyLink xlink:href="1b3160de-64e9-40d1-89eb-af3e0fd6acf0">RECT</legacyLink> data structure. Have the application unlock that memory with the                         <externalLink> <linkText>GlobalUnlock</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/aa366595</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function before it yields or returns control.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onsizing">
        <!--71d5e3f6-dd82-437f-a319-71c377cfb632-->
        <title>CWnd::OnSizing</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function to indicate that the user is resizing the rectangle.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnSizing(
    UINT nSide,
    LPRECT lpRect );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nSide</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>The edge of window to be moved.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>lpRect</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Address of the <legacyLink xlink:href="dee4e752-15d6-4db4-b68f-1ad65b2ed6ca">CRect</legacyLink> or <legacyLink xlink:href="1b3160de-64e9-40d1-89eb-af3e0fd6acf0">RECT</legacyLink> structure that will contain the item's coordinates.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>By processing this message, an application can monitor the size and position of the drag rectangle and, if needed, change its size or position.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Example</title>
                <content>
                    <codeReference>NVC_MFCWindowing#110</codeReference>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onspoolerstatus">
        <!--6634be21-a213-409a-8102-5887cae15525-->
        <title>CWnd::OnSpoolerStatus</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function from Print Manager whenever a job is added to or removed from the Print Manager queue.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnSpoolerStatus(
    UINT nStatus,
    UINT nJobs );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nStatus</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the <legacyBold>SP_JOBSTATUS</legacyBold> flag.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm>
                            <legacyItalic>nJobs</legacyItalic>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the number of jobs remaining in the Print Manager queue.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This call is for informational purposes only.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onstylechanged">
        <!--f03eeeee-3cd9-4ba2-ae76-6b1a2a825711-->
        <title>CWnd::OnStyleChanged</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function after the                 <externalLink> <linkText>SetWindowLong</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms633591</linkUri>
                </externalLink> function has changed one or more of the window's styles.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnStyleChanged(
    int nStyleType,
    LPSTYLESTRUCT lpStyleStruct );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nStyleType</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies whether the window's extended or nonextended styles have changed. This parameter can be a combination of the following values:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>GWL_EXSTYLE</legacyBold>The window's extended styles have changed.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>GWL_STYLE</legacyBold>The window's nonextended styles have changed.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>lpStyleStruct</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Points to a                                 <externalLink> <linkText>STYLESTRUCT</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms632607</linkUri>
                                </externalLink> structure that contains the new styles for the window. An application can examine the styles, but it can not change them.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onstylechanging">
        <!--8e0727ab-3c41-4340-bbf4-003b55105311-->
        <title>CWnd::OnStyleChanging</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the                 <externalLink> <linkText>SetWindowLong</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms633591</linkUri>
                </externalLink> function is about to change one or more of the window's styles.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnStyleChanging(
    int nStyleType,
    LPSTYLESTRUCT lpStyleStruct );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nStyleType</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies whether the window's extended or nonextended styles have changed. This parameter can be a combination of the following values:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>GWL_EXSTYLE</legacyBold>The window's extended styles have changed.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>GWL_STYLE</legacyBold>The window's nonextended styles have changed.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>lpStyleStruct</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Points to a                                 <externalLink> <linkText>STYLESTRUCT</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms632607</linkUri>
                                </externalLink> structure that contains the new styles for the window. An application can examine the styles and change them.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onsyschar">
        <!--cbda8967-7756-4c54-8538-b2d1229f68c3-->
        <title>CWnd::OnSysChar</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function if <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> has the input focus and the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onsyskeyup">WM_SYSKEYUP</legacyLink> and <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onsyskeydown">WM_SYSKEYDOWN</legacyLink> messages are translated.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnSysChar(
    UINT nChar,
    UINT nRepCnt,
    UINT nFlags );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nChar</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the ASCII-character key code of a Control-menu key.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nRepCnt</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the repeat count (the number of times the keystroke is repeated as a result of the user holding down the key).</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>The <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference> parameter can have these values:</para>
                            <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                                <thead>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Value</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Meaning</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                </thead>
                                <tbody>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>0-15</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Specifies the repeat count. The value is the number of times the keystroke is repeated as a result of the user holding down the key..</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>16-23</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Specifies the scan code. The value depends on the original equipment manufacturer (OEM)</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>24</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Specifies whether the key is an extended key, such as the right-hand ALT and CTRL keys that appear on an enhanced 101- or 102-key keyboard. The value is 1 if it is an extended key; otherwise, it is 0.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>25-28</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Used internally by Windows.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>29</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Specifies the context code. The value is 1 if the ALT key is held down while the key is pressed; otherwise, the value is 0.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>30</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Specifies the previous key state. The value is 1 if the key is down before the message is sent, or it is 0 if the key is up.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>31</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Specifies the transition state. The value is 1 if the key is being released, or it is 0 if the key is being pressed.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                </tbody>
                            </table>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>It specifies the virtual key code of the Control-menu key. (For a list of of standard virtual key codes, see Winuser.h)</para>
                    <para>When the context code is 0, <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_SYSCHAR</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> can pass the                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_SYSCHAR</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms646357</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> message to the                         <externalLink> <linkText>TranslateAccelerator</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms646373</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function, which will handle it as though it were a normal key message instead of a system character-key. This allows accelerator keys to be used with the active window even if the active window does not have the input focus.</para>
                    <para>For IBM Enhanced 101- and 102-key keyboards, enhanced keys are the right ALT and the right CTRL keys on the main section of the keyboard; the INS, DEL, HOME, END, PAGE UP, PAGE DOWN, and arrow keys in the clusters to the left of the numeric keypad; and the slash (/) and ENTER keys in the numeric keypad. Some other keyboards may support the extended-key bit in <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onsyscolorchange">
        <!--3f0a2263-e9ac-4a93-a3fc-6405f0bb2696-->
        <title>CWnd::OnSysColorChange</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function for all top-level windows when a change is made in the system color setting.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnSysColorChange();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Windows calls <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysColorChange</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> for any window that is affected by a system color change. </para>
                    <para>Applications that have brushes that use the existing system colors should delete those brushes and re-create them with the new system colors.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onsyscommand">
        <!--b5281236-5c1e-499d-9633-3bb3464a6ea1-->
        <title>CWnd::OnSysCommand</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the user selects a command from the Control menu, or when the user selects the Maximize or the Minimize button.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnSysCommand(
    UINT nID,
    LPARAM lParam );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nID</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the type of system command requested. This parameter can be any one of the following values:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_CLOSE</legacyBold>Close the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_HOTKEY</legacyBold>Activate the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object associated with the application-specified hot key. The low-order word of <parameterReference>lParam</parameterReference> identifies the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>HWND</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> of the window to activate. </para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_HSCROLL</legacyBold>Scroll horizontally.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_KEYMENU</legacyBold>Retrieve a menu through a keystroke.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_MAXIMIZE</legacyBold> (or <legacyBold>SC_ZOOM</legacyBold>)Maximize the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_MINIMIZE</legacyBold> (or <legacyBold>SC_ICON</legacyBold>)Minimize the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_MOUSEMENU</legacyBold>Retrieve a menu through a mouse click.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_MOVE</legacyBold>Move the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_NEXTWINDOW</legacyBold>Move to the next window.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_PREVWINDOW</legacyBold>Move to the previous window.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_RESTORE</legacyBold>Restore window to normal position and size.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_SCREENSAVE</legacyBold>Executes the screen-saver application specified in the [boot] section of the SYSTEM.INI file.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_SIZE</legacyBold>Size the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_TASKLIST</legacyBold>Execute or activate the Windows Task Manager application.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_VSCROLL</legacyBold>Scroll vertically.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>lParam</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>If a Control-menu command is chosen with the mouse, <parameterReference>lParam</parameterReference> contains the cursor coordinates. The low-order word contains the x coordinate, and the high-order word contains the y coordinate. Otherwise this parameter is not used.</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_HOTKEY</legacyBold>Activate the window associated with the application-specified hot key. The low-order word of <parameterReference>lParam</parameterReference> identifies the window to activate.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>SC_SCREENSAVE</legacyBold>Execute the screen-save application specified in the Desktop section of Control Panel.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>By default, <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysCommand</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> carries out the Control-menu request for the predefined actions specified in the preceding table. </para>
                    <para>In <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_SYSCOMMAND</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> messages, the four low-order bits of the <parameterReference>nID</parameterReference> parameter are used internally by Windows. When an application tests the value of <parameterReference>nID</parameterReference>, it must combine the value 0xFFF0 with the <parameterReference>nID</parameterReference> value by using the bitwise-AND operator to obtain the correct result.</para>
                    <para>The menu items in a Control menu can be modified with the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>GetSystemMenu</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>AppendMenu</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>InsertMenu</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>, and <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>ModifyMenu</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member functions. Applications that modify the Control menu must process <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_SYSCOMMAND</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> messages, and any <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_SYSCOMMAND</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> messages not handled by the application must be passed on to <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysCommand</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>. Any command values added by an application must be processed by the application and cannot be passed to <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysCommand</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>.</para>
                    <para>An application can carry out any system command at any time by passing a <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_SYSCOMMAND</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message to <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysCommand</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>. </para>
                    <para>Accelerator (shortcut) keystrokes that are defined to select items from the Control menu are translated into <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysCommand</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> calls; all other accelerator keystrokes are translated into <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__oncommand">WM_COMMAND</legacyLink> messages.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onsysdeadchar">
        <!--70083c9f-15f8-4467-8c53-cfb0dd0711f7-->
        <title>CWnd::OnSysDeadChar</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function if the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object has the input focus when the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onsyskeyup">OnSysKeyUp</legacyLink> or <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onsyskeydown">OnSysKeyDown</legacyLink> member function is called.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnSysDeadChar(
    UINT nChar,
    UINT nRepCnt,
    UINT nFlags );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nChar</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the dead-key character value.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nRepCnt</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the repeat count.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the scan code, key-transition code, previous key state, and context code, as shown in the following list:</para>
                            <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                                <thead>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Value</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Meaning</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                </thead>
                                <tbody>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>07</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Scan code (OEM-dependent value). Low byte of high-order word.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>8</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Extended key, such as a function key or a key on the numeric keypad (1 if it is an extended key; otherwise 0).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>910</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Not used.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>1112</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Used internally by Windows.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>13</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Context code (1 if the ALT key is held down while the key is pressed; otherwise 0).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>14</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Previous key state (1 if the key is down before the call, 0 if the key is up).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>15</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Transition state (1 if the key is being released, 0 if the key is being pressed).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                </tbody>
                            </table>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>It specifies the character value of a dead key.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onsyskeydown">
        <!--68c2799d-a90f-42ec-955d-2ce794d82d84-->
        <title>CWnd::OnSysKeyDown</title>
        <content>
            <para>If the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object has the input focus, the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysKeyDown</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function is called by the framework when the user holds down the ALT key and then presses another key.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnSysKeyDown(
    UINT nChar,
    UINT nRepCnt,
    UINT nFlags );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nChar</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the virtual key code of the key being pressed. For a list of of standard virtual key codes, see Winuser.h</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nRepCnt</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the repeat count.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the scan code, key-transition code, previous key state, and context code, as shown in the following list:</para>
                            <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                                <thead>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Value</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Meaning</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                </thead>
                                <tbody>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>07</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Scan code (OEM-dependent value). Low byte of high-order word.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>8</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Extended key, such as a function key or a key on the numeric keypad (1 if it is an extended key; otherwise 0).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>910</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Not used.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>1112</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Used internally by Windows.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>13</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Context code (1 if the ALT key is held down while the key is pressed, 0 otherwise).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>14</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Previous key state (1 if the key is down before the message is sent, 0 if the key is up).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>15</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Transition state (1 if the key is being released, 0 if the key is being pressed).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                </tbody>
                            </table>
                            <para>For <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysKeyDown</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> calls, the key-transition bit (bit 15) is 0. The context-code bit (bit 13) is 1 if the ALT key is down while the key is pressed; it is 0 if the message is sent to the active window because no window has the input focus. </para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>If no window currently has the input focus, the active window's <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysKeyDown</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function is called. The <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object that receives the message can distinguish between these two contexts by checking the context code in <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>. </para>
                    <para>When the context code is 0, the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_SYSKEYDOWN</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message received by <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysKeyDown</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> can be passed to the                         <externalLink> <linkText>TranslateAccelerator</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms646373</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function, which will handle it as though it were a normal key message instead of a system-key message. This allows accelerator keys to be used with the active window even if the active window does not have the input focus.</para>
                    <para>Because of auto-repeat, more than one <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysKeyDown</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> call may occur before the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onsyskeyup">WM_SYSKEYUP</legacyLink> message is received. The previous key state (bit 14) can be used to determine whether the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysKeyDown</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> call indicates the first down transition or a repeated down transition.</para>
                    <para>For IBM Enhanced 101- and 102-key keyboards, enhanced keys are the right ALT and the right CTRL keys on the main section of the keyboard; the INS, DEL, HOME, END, PAGE UP, PAGE DOWN, and arrow keys in the clusters to the left of the numeric keypad; and the slash (/) and ENTER keys in the numeric keypad. Some other keyboards may support the extended-key bit in <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onsyskeyup">
        <!--3f33909d-a0b3-4250-ba0a-6b0bcb76ebc5-->
        <title>CWnd::OnSysKeyUp</title>
        <content>
            <para>If the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object has the focus, the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysKeyUp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function is called by the framework when the user releases a key that was pressed while the ALT key was held down.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnSysKeyUp(
    UINT nChar,
    UINT nRepCnt,
    UINT nFlags );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nChar</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the virtual key code of the key being pressed. For a list of of standard virtual key codes, see Winuser.h</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nRepCnt</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the repeat count.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the scan code, key-transition code, previous key state, and context code, as shown in the following list:</para>
                            <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                                <thead>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Value</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Meaning</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                </thead>
                                <tbody>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>07</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Scan code (OEM-dependent value). Low byte of high-order word.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>8</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Extended key, such as a function key or a key on the numeric keypad (1 if it is an extended key; otherwise 0).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>910</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Not used.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>1112</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Used internally by Windows.</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>13</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Context code (1 if the ALT key is held down while the key is pressed, 0 otherwise).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>14</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Previous key state (1 if the key is down before the message is sent, 0 if the key is up).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                    <tr>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>15</para>
                                        </TD>
                                        <TD>
                                            <para>Transition state (1 if the key is being released, 0 if the key is being pressed).</para>
                                        </TD>
                                    </tr>
                                </tbody>
                            </table>
                            <para>For <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysKeyUp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> calls, the key-transition bit (bit 15) is 1. The context-code bit (bit 13) is 1 if the ALT key is down while the key is pressed; it is 0 if the message is sent to the active window because no window has the input focus. </para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>If no window currently has the input focus, the active window's <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysKeyUp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> member function is called. The <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>CWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> object that receives the call can distinguish between these two contexts by checking the context code in <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>. </para>
                    <para>When the context code is 0, the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_SYSKEYUP</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message received by <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnSysKeyUp</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> can be passed to the                         <externalLink> <linkText>TranslateAccelerator</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms646373</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function, which will handle it as though it were a normal key message instead of a system-key message. This allows accelerator (shortcut) keys to be used with the active window even if the active window does not have the input focus.</para>
                    <para>For IBM Enhanced 101- and 102-key keyboards, enhanced keys are the right ALT and the right CTRL keys on the main section of the keyboard; the INS, DEL, HOME, END, PAGE UP, PAGE DOWN, and arrow keys in the clusters to the left of the numeric keypad; and the slash (/) and ENTER keys in the numeric keypad. Some other keyboards may support the extended-key bit in <parameterReference>nFlags</parameterReference>.</para>
                    <para>For non-U.S. Enhanced 102-key keyboards, the right ALT key is handled as the CTRL+ALT key combination. The following shows the sequence of messages and calls that result when the user presses and releases this key:</para>
                    <table xmlns:caps="http://schemas.microsoft.com/build/caps/2013/11">
                        <thead>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Sequence</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Function Accessed</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>Message Passed</para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </thead>
                        <tbody>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>1.</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para> <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onkeydown">WM_KEYDOWN</legacyLink>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>VK_CONTROL</legacyBold>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>2.</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para> <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onkeydown">WM_KEYDOWN</legacyLink>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>VK_MENU</legacyBold>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>3.</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para> <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__onkeyup">WM_KEYUP</legacyLink>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>VK_CONTROL</legacyBold>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                            <tr>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>4.</para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para>
                                        <externalLink> <linkText>WM_SYSKEYUP</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms646287</linkUri>
                                        </externalLink>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                                <TD>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>VK_MENU</legacyBold>
                                    </para>
                                </TD>
                            </tr>
                        </tbody>
                    </table>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ontcard">
        <!--f627b838-4695-499a-bd97-7361e510946f-->
        <title>CWnd::OnTCard</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when the user clicks an authorable button.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnTCard(
    UINT idAction,
    DWORD dwActionData );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>idAction</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Indicates the action the user has taken. This parameter can be one of these values:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>IDABORT</legacyBold>The user clicked an authorable Abort button.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>IDCANCEL</legacyBold>The user clicked an authorable Cancel button.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>IDCLOSE</legacyBold>The user closed the training card.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>IDHELP</legacyBold>The user clicked an authorable Windows Help button.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>IDIGNORE</legacyBold>The user clicked an authorable Ignore button.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>IDOK</legacyBold>The user clicked an authorable OK button.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>IDNO</legacyBold>The user clicked an authorable No button.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>IDRETRY</legacyBold>The user clicked an authorable Retry button.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>HELP_TCARD_DATA</legacyBold>The user clicked an authorable button. The <parameterReference>dwActionData</parameterReference> parameter contains a long integer specified by the help author.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>HELP_TCARD_NEXT</legacyBold>The user clicked an authorable Next button.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>HELP_TCARD_OTHER_CALLER</legacyBold>Another application has requested training cards.</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <legacyBold>IDYES</legacyBold>The user clicked an authorable Yes button.</para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>dwActionData</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>If <parameterReference>idAction</parameterReference> specifies <legacyBold>HELP_TCARD_DATA</legacyBold>, this parameter is a long integer specified by the help author. Otherwise, this parameter is zero.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>This function is called only when an application has initiated a training card with Windows Help. An application initiates a training card by specifying the <legacyBold>HELP_TCARD</legacyBold> command in a call to the <legacyLink xlink:href="e426a3cd-0d15-40d6-bd55-beaa5feb2343#cwinapp__winhelp">WinHelp</legacyLink> function.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ontimechange">
        <!--e09a0c2a-bcb1-48ae-9bf6-47ad12c5174f-->
        <title>CWnd::OnTimeChange</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function after the system time is changed.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnTimeChange();</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>Have any application that changes the system time send this message to all top-level windows. To send the <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>WM_TIMECHANGE</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> message to all top-level windows, an application can use the                         <externalLink> <linkText>SendMessage</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms644950</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function with its                         <legacyItalic>hwnd</legacyItalic> parameter set to <legacyBold>HWND_BROADCAST</legacyBold>.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ontimer">
        <!--eaeaa6af-fcf0-4185-b7d6-67fd16c500b7-->
        <title>CWnd::OnTimer</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function after each interval specified in the <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__settimer">SetTimer</legacyLink> member function used to install a timer.</para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnTimer( UINT_PTR nIDEvent );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nIDEvent</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the identifier of the timer.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>The                         <externalLink> <linkText>DispatchMessage</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms644934</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> Windows function sends a                         <externalLink> <linkText>WM_TIMER</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms644902</linkUri>
                        </externalLink> message when no other messages are in the application's message queue.</para>
                    <alert class="note">
                        <para>This member function is called by the framework to allow your application to handle a Windows message. The parameters passed to your function reflect the parameters received by the framework when the message was received. If you call the base-class implementation of this function, that implementation will use the parameters originally passed with the message and not the parameters you supply to the function.</para>
                    </alert>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Example</title>
                <content>
                    <!--startsnip-->
                            <para>See the example in <legacyLink xlink:href="#cwnd__settimer">CWnd::SetTimer</legacyLink>.</para>
                        <!--endsnip-->
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ontoolhittest">
        <!--130cdf57-2aec-4173-90d4-c2bd9c84dbd5-->
        <title>CWnd::OnToolHitTest</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function to detemine whether a point is in the bounding rectangle of the specified tool.</para>
            <legacySyntax>virtual INT_PTR OnToolHitTest(
    CPoint point,
    TOOLINFO* pTI ) const;</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>point</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Specifies the x- and y-coordinate of the cursor. These coordinates are always relative to the upper-left corner of the window</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pTI</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>A pointer to a                                 <externalLink> <linkText>TOOLINFO</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/bb760256</linkUri>
                                </externalLink> structure. The following structure values are set by default:</para>
                            <list class="bullet">
                                <listItem>
                                    <para>
                                        <legacyItalic>hwnd</legacyItalic> = <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>m_hWnd</unmanagedCodeEntityReference>Handle to a window</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <parameterReference>uId</parameterReference> = <legacyBold>(UINT)hWndChild</legacyBold>Handle to a child window</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <parameterReference>uFlags</parameterReference> |= <legacyBold>TTF_IDISHWND</legacyBold>Handle of the tool</para>
                                </listItem>
                                <listItem>
                                    <para> <parameterReference>lpszText</parameterReference> = <legacyBold>LPSTR_TEXTCALLBACK</legacyBold>Pointer to the string that is to be displayed in the specified window </para>
                                </listItem>
                            </list>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para>If the tooltip control was found, the window control ID. If the tooltip control was not found, -1.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content>
                    <para>If the point is in the rectangle, it retrieves information about the tool.</para>
                    <para>If the area with which the tooltip is associated is not a button, <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnToolHitTest</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> sets the structure flags to <legacyBold>TTF_NOTBUTTON</legacyBold> and <legacyBold>TTF_CENTERTIP</legacyBold>. </para>
                    <para>Override <unmanagedCodeEntityReference>OnToolHitTest</unmanagedCodeEntityReference> to provide different information than the default provides.</para>
                    <para>See                         <externalLink> <linkText>TOOLINFO</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/bb760256</linkUri>
                        </externalLink>, in the <token>winSDK</token>, for more information about the structure.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ontouchinput">
        <!--d6879a53-9aac-4c06-af4a-ea6345bd3e31-->
        <title>CWnd::OnTouchInput</title>
        <content>
            <para>Process single input from Windows touch.</para>
            <legacySyntax>virtual BOOL OnTouchInput(
    CPoint pt,
    int nInputNumber,
    int nInputsCount,
    PTOUCHINPUT pInput );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pt</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Point where screen has been touched (in the client coordinates).</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nInputNumber</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Number of touch input.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nInputsCount</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Total number of touch inputs.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pInput</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Pointer to TOUCHINPUT structure.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para> <languageKeyword>TRUE</languageKeyword> if the application processes Windows touch input; otherwise <languageKeyword>FALSE</languageKeyword>.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content/>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__ontouchinputs">
        <!--75b0ff87-28c6-4b4c-9521-c44a95a8e411-->
        <title>CWnd::OnTouchInputs</title>
        <content>
            <para>Processes inputs from Windows touch.</para>
            <legacySyntax>virtual BOOL OnTouchInputs(
    UINT nInputsCount,
    PTOUCHINPUT pInputs );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
                <content>
                    <definitionTable>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>nInputsCount</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Total number of Windows touch inputs.</para>
                        </definition>
                        <definedTerm> <parameterReference>pInputs</parameterReference>
                        </definedTerm>
                        <definition>
                            <para>Array of TOUCHINPUT.</para>
                        </definition>
                    </definitionTable>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Return Value</title>
                <content>
                    <para> <languageKeyword>TRUE</languageKeyword> if application processes Windows touch inputs; otherwise <languageKeyword>FALSE</languageKeyword>.</para>
                </content>
            </section>
            <section>
                <title>Remarks</title>
                <content/>
            </section>
        </sections>
    </section>
    <section address="cwnd__onunichar">
        <!--8a6098d2-bb7e-47b1-bb43-63a911f2c3f7-->
        <title>CWnd::OnUniChar</title>
        <content>
            <para>The framework calls this member function when a key is pressed. That is, the current window has the keyboard focus and a                 <externalLink> <linkText>WM_KEYDOWN</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms646280</linkUri>
                </externalLink> message is translated by the                 <externalLink> <linkText>TranslateMessage</linkText> <linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms644955</linkUri>
                </externalLink> function. </para>
            <legacySyntax>afx_msg void OnUniChar(
    UINT nChar, 
    UINT nRepCnt, 
    UINT nFlags );</legacySyntax>
        </content>
        <sections>
            <section>
                <title>Parameters</title>
